commit_message:
Using Rally for functional in tree testing

Change-Id: I666496a5ac67735785d34b8e044801cfc753f3be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/56/151756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html =================================== Using Rally for functional testing =================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/functional-test-based-on-rally We can use Rally for functional, regression, performance, scale testing instead of implementing own framework for testing and integrating it in gates. Rally is data driven heavy pluggable and very well integrated in gates tool. That allows you to create good functional coverage using small amount of code. Problem description =================== Functional testing based on Tempest has few issues: * Tests are done after features. This leads that non working features can be merged. * Gate scale issue. All Tempest tests are run against all patches in all projects. This doesn't allow Heat team for example to add 1hrs of Heat related tests. * Tempest team scale issue. All functional tests should be merged in tempest and reviewed by tempest core team. This process can take a lot of time. Functional testing in tree (based on functional-tests.rst) has as well issues: * It is pain for Operators that would like to check does their cloud work. They will need to run all functional tests from all projects separately and somehow combine results. * Functional tests based on unittest like framework is not a good idea: * It produce a lot of tests duplication (like N tests that test stack create command). * It doesn't allow you to work on races. For example if you would like to work on various * It can't be used for performance/load/regression/negative testing and so on Rally has already way to resolve this issues.. Proposed change =============== Rally is heavy pluggable data driven framework and tool for testing. You have 4 kinds of plugins: * Scenario - set of actions that is performed by user/admin * Runner - things that runs multiple time Scenarios to generate load that you need. * Context - it is equal to setUp() tearDown() in unitest. It allows you to create required users, tenants and so on before doing load. * SLA - criteria of success that allows you to specify what means that test finished successfully. Like avarage duration of iterations is less then some value, and there is no failures in scenarios. One more thing is that all these plugins are parametrized. Like Scenario can accept path to Heat Template that should be created and deleted. Runner what load to generate, Context amount of users to create and so on. So to use Rally you should have 2 things: * Plugins that makes what you want * Input task file that creates set of tests combining these plugins Rally input task format is quite simple. {<SceanarioName>: [<BenchamrkConfiguration>]} where <BenchmarkConfiguration> is: { "args": <dict_with_arguments_that_are_passed_to_scenario>, "runner": { "type": <runner_plugin_name>, <arg_passed_to_runner>: <value_passed_to_runner> }, "context": { <context_plugin_name>: <dict_with_args_passed_to_context_plugin> }, "sla": { <sla_plugin>: <dict_with_args_passed_to_plugin> } } So for example: HeatStacks.create_and_delete_stack: - args: template_path: '/home/jenkins/.rally/extra/server_with_volume.yaml.template' runner: type: "constant" times: 4 concurrency: 2 context: users: tenants: 2 users_per_tenant: 2 quotas: nova: cpu: -1 sla: failure_rate: max: 0 It will use HeatStack.create_and_delete_stack scenario. That can be found here: https://github.com/stackforge/rally/blob/master/rally/benchmark/scenarios/heat/stacks.py#L61 This scenario will be run 4 times. In the any moment of time we will have 2 running scenarios. (that is why constant runner is called so). And before running this scenario we will create 2 tenants, in each tenant we will create 2 users. After that we will setup nova "cpu" quota for all created tenants to "-1". And the criteria of success will be that there were no exceptions during any of run of scenario. Btw if we remove this criteria test will always pass. Such flexibility allows us to do next things: *) Work on races (as we can specify what load to generate) *) Small amount of code can cover a lot of functionality *) Put regression criteria. Like average duration for some test should be less then some value. *) Run unstable tests in gates on every patch (just remove sla criteria) *) Testing impact on performance/scale of proposed patches. Like we can use fake job and create any amount of resources and get numbers. *) In future. Tracing OpenStack requests with Rally and OSprofiler in gates Alternatives ------------ Keep working on Heat in-tree functional framework. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: boris-42 Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Kilo-3 Work Items ---------- * Switch Rally job to use Rally releases instead of master. So Rally team won't be able to break Heat gates. Plus it will allow Rally team to work on new versions and make sometimes non backward compable changes. * Run Rally on every patch (instead of experimental job) * Configure Rally job to use heat scenarios on 100% * Start writing more Rally plugins if they are required in Heat source tree Dependencies ============ Change infra job to add ability to setup specific rally release.

commit_message:
Automate tempest config generation

This blueprint will contain enough information to build a tool that
will generate proper tempest.conf using few input arguments

Co-Authored-By: Andrey Kurilin <akurilin@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I2ed8cc4c998f2037b6b3e235d014a723dfdd801f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/73/94473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. ================================== Automate tempest config generation ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/<not-yet-there> Automate tempest config generation. Problem description =================== Currently tempest config has more then 200 options. In future there will be more & more options. It goes without saying words that writing by hand tempest.conf is hard task. This work should be and can be fully automated. So let's do it! Proposed change =============== Make a script that accept as few as possible arguments and generate proper tempest configuration. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-3 Work Items ---------- - Make a table with all arguments - Split arguments to 4 groups: -- Should be specified (administrators credentials) --

commit_message:
Add cleanup for Neutron v2 lbaas pool

Neutron uses 'pool' as v1 lbaas's resource name, and 'lbaas_pool' as v2
lbaas pool. This patch is to cleanup v2 pool for related bug.

Change-Id: Ib4362c3fa12592f55ffe76d4d9f092d7ce44a99b
Partial-Bug: #1470330
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/98/214998/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow more instance operations during live migration

This spec proposes a change to Nova to allow an operator
or user to perform more actions on an instance while it
is being live migrated. The actions are all ones which
exist in Nova already but are currently blocked.

Change-Id: Ibe96d4fba21206298f7eb76467c72437c148e8f4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/46/179346/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== Allow More Instance Operations During a Live Migration ====================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/enhance-instance-operations-during-live-migration Currently the only operation a user can perform on an instance which is being live-migrated is "delete". Block migration can take several hours for a large and busy instance, so it would be better for a user if those operations which are logically possible during a migration were allowed. Problem description =================== An operator might well want to use live migration to manage workloads, for reasons such as node maintenance or upgrade, datacenter management, or noisy-neighbor management. This currently prevents the user from doing a lot of instance actions for the duration, and a block live migration of a busy instance can take a long time. In fact, for example the migration might be significantly faster if the instance became paused but there's no way to do that. Use Cases ---------- * As a user of an OpenStack cloud, I would like to be able to manage my instances while a live migration is taking place. * As an admin of an OpenStack cloud, I would like to be able to use live migration for operational purposes with less inconvenience to my users. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== There are many operations which could be allowed during a live migration. It may not be practical to implement all of these, but in rough priority order: * pause / unpause * reboot * stop / start * volume-attach / volume-detach * console-log * lock / unlock * get-vnc-console * rebuild * rescue / unrescue * rename * shelve / unshelve The implementation would apply the operation immediately if possible, otherwise apply the operation to the instance after migration (ie on the target if the migration succeeds, or the source if it doesn't) Alternatives ------------ This is new functionality. The primary alternative is to not add it, and leave the users and operators with the same choices the have today. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The API remains unchanged, however some operations will change their response from 409/Conflict into a success response when called during task_state.MIGRATING. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None anticipated Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Matthew Gilliard (irc: gilliard) Work Items ---------- * As described in the "Proposed Change" section. Each item there corresponds to a single work item. * Enhancement to the Tempest virt driver used in live migration tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unit and Functional tests in Nova * If it is possible to modify the virt driver used by tempest to guarantee that a live migration can be made to take enough time that these operations can be performed, then Tempest tests can be written. This would be preferable. Documentation Impact ==================== These changes need to be documented in user and operator documentation. References ========== None

commit_message:
Fix 500 error when adding pool to wrong group

For different database type, they should be put in different groups
since they have different capabilities. When adding new pool to
wrong group, HTTP 400 BadRequest should be returned instead of 500.
This patch fixes it and adds unit test for that.

Closes-Bug: #1489879

Change-Id: I130c0bbafc047b44f73c456b99692173bc91079e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/22/221122/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix client disconnect during multhiphase commit

This patch add a test to figure out the failure case behavior of
object-server when the connection from proxy-server disconnected
during commit phase. Especially, this patch was made to focus on
making sure whether or not contaienr updates occurs in the situation.

In the process of working on that test we made the behavior of the
object-server when the connection from the proxy-server disconnected
during the commit phase - reasonable.

We capture the IOError/ValueError's that eventlet.wsgi might barf out
really close to the wsgi_input read and translate them to a
swift.common.exceptions.ChunkReadError so we can handle them at a higher
level in the ObjectController's generic PUT disconnect handling.

Since that test went so well, we refactored the other ones to use some
common context management and wrote a few more.

Co-Author: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I60c98172e524869b06bdf23fd1c4e1bce7a98f80
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/87/224387/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

from contextlib import contextmanager, nestedfrom swift.common.swob import Request, HeaderKeyDict, WsgiBytesIO, \ HTTPClientDisconnect def test_multiphase_put_client_disconnect_at_commit(self): test_data = 'obj data' footer_meta = { "X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Frag-Index": "2", "Etag": md5(test_data).hexdigest(), } footer_json = json.dumps(footer_meta) footer_meta_cksum = md5(footer_json).hexdigest() test_doc = "
".join(( "--boundary123", "X-Document: object body", "", test_data, "--boundary123", "X-Document: object metadata", "Content-MD5: " + footer_meta_cksum, "", footer_json, "--boundary123", )) # phase1 - PUT request with object metadata in footer and # multiphase commit conversation put_timestamp = utils.Timestamp(time()).internal headers = { 'Content-Type': 'text/plain', 'X-Timestamp': put_timestamp, 'Transfer-Encoding': 'chunked', 'Expect': '100-continue', 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index': '1', 'X-Backend-Obj-Content-Length': len(test_data), 'X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer': 'yes', 'X-Backend-Obj-Multipart-Mime-Boundary': 'boundary123', 'X-Backend-Obj-Multiphase-Commit': 'yes', } read_commit = \ 'swift.obj.server.ObjectController._read_put_commit_message' container_update = \ 'swift.obj.server.ObjectController.container_update' with nested(mock.patch(read_commit), mock.patch(container_update)) as \ (_read_commit_call, _container_update): _read_commit_call.side_effect = HTTPClientDisconnect() conn = bufferedhttp.http_connect('127.0.0.1', self.port, 'sda1', '0', 'PUT', '/a/c/o', headers=headers) resp = conn.getexpect() self.assertEqual(resp.status, 100) headers = HeaderKeyDict(resp.getheaders()) self.assertEqual(headers['X-Obj-Multiphase-Commit'], 'yes') self.assertEqual(headers['X-Obj-Metadata-Footer'], 'yes') to_send = "%x
%s
0

" % (len(test_doc), test_doc) conn.send(to_send) # verify 100-continue response to mark end of phase1 resp = conn.getexpect() self.assertEqual(resp.status, 100) # send commit confirmation to start phase2 commit_confirmation_doc = "
".join(( "X-Document: put commit", "", "commit_confirmation", "--boundary123--", )) to_send = "%x
%s
0

" % \ (len(commit_confirmation_doc), commit_confirmation_doc) conn.send(to_send) # failed at commit resp = conn.getresponse() self.assertEqual(resp.status, 499) resp.read() resp.close() # verify successful object data and durable state file write obj_basename = os.path.join( self.devices, 'sda1', storage_directory(diskfile.get_data_dir(POLICIES[1]), '0', hash_path('a', 'c', 'o')), put_timestamp) # .data file is there obj_datafile = obj_basename + '#2.data' self.assertTrue(os.path.isfile(obj_datafile)) # but .durable isn't obj_durablefile = obj_basename + '.durable' self.assertFalse(os.path.isfile(obj_durablefile)) # And no continer update self.assertFalse(_container_update.called)

commit_message:
Handle replace and rollback cases for Port

Add prepare_for_replace and restore_after_rollback methods for port
resource. Now if port has fixed_ip address it will be correctly handled
during UpdateReplace, i.e. we detach this ip and store it in self.data.
In case, when rollback happens, fixed_ips data will be taken from
self.data of resource in _backup_stack.

Follow functional tests was added:
 - enable test with simple replacing port
 - test for failed update with rollback
 - test for failed update without rollback and second repair update

implements bp rich-network-prop

Change-Id: Id3877ed8cb1097f6c93725806d137ea67ab07466
Closes-Bug: #1455100

added_lines: import mockfrom oslo_serialization import jsonutils def test_prepare_for_replace_port(self): t = template_format.parse(neutron_port_template) stack = utils.parse_stack(t) port = stack['port'] port.resource_id = 'test_res_id' _value = { 'fixed_ips': { 'subnet_id': 'test_subnet', 'ip_address': '42.42.42.42' } } port._show_resource = mock.Mock(return_value=_value) port.data_set = mock.Mock() n_client = mock.Mock() port.neutron = mock.Mock(return_value=n_client) # execute prepare_for_replace port.prepare_for_replace() # check, that data was stored port.data_set.assert_called_once_with( 'port_fip', jsonutils.dumps(_value.get('fixed_ips'))) # check, that port was updated and ip was removed expected_props = {'port': {'fixed_ips': []}} n_client.update_port.assert_called_once_with('test_res_id', expected_props) def test_restore_after_rollback_port(self): t = template_format.parse(neutron_port_template) stack = utils.parse_stack(t) new_port = stack['port'] new_port.resource_id = 'new_res_id' # mock backup stack to return only one mocked old_port old_port = mock.Mock() new_port.stack._backup_stack = mock.Mock() new_port.stack._backup_stack().resources.get.return_value = old_port old_port.resource_id = 'old_res_id' _value = { 'subnet_id': 'test_subnet', 'ip_address': '42.42.42.42' } old_port.data = mock.Mock( return_value={'port_fip': jsonutils.dumps(_value)}) n_client = mock.Mock() new_port.neutron = mock.Mock(return_value=n_client) # execute prepare_for_replace new_port.restore_after_rollback() # check, that ports were updated: old port get ip and # same ip was removed from old port expected_new_props = {'port': {'fixed_ips': []}} expected_old_props = {'port': {'fixed_ips': _value}} n_client.update_port.has_calls(('new_res_id', expected_new_props), ('old_res_id', expected_old_props))

commit_message:
Use root_stack_id for stack_count_total_resources

The current implementation of stack_count_total_resources
scales very poorly for stacks with many nested stacks.

This change replaces the implementation with a single count
query filtering on the resource.root_stack_id column.

The following template was used for performance testing:

heat_template_version: 2015-04-30
description: >
  Stress test, create many stacks in a RG
parameters:
  count:
    type: number
    default: 4
resources:
  dummies:
    type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
    properties:
      count: {get_param: count}
      resource_def:
        type: dummy_node.yaml

 # dummy_node.yaml
heat_template_version: 2015-04-30
parameters:
resources:
  random:
    type: OS::Heat::RandomString
  randoms:
    type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
    properties:
      count: 1
      resource_def:
        type: OS::Heat::RandomString

This template was used to time the stack creation with
count=40 and count=80 against heat-master, the previous
change I2b00285514235834131222012408d2b5b2b37d30
and this change. Here are the results:

 Stack heat-master-40 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    1m9.103s

 Stack root-stack-id-40 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    0m59.233s

 Stack count-total-resources-40 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    0m43.308s

 Stack heat-master-80 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    2m47.190s

 Stack root-stack-id-80 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    2m16.743s

 Stack count-total-resources-80 CREATE_COMPLETE
real    1m15.288s

Also, the test template in bug #1489548 took 3 minutes
to create (vs the originally reported 13 minutes).

Change-Id: Iab3eaaba3ece16e14db3231f1c725bca3c8985c2
Closes-Bug: 1489548
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/35/226135/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # start with a stack_get to confirm the context can access the stack if stack_id is None or stack_get(context, stack_id) is None: return 0 def nested_stack_ids(sid): yield sid for child in stack_get_all_by_owner_id(context, sid): for stack in nested_stack_ids(child.id): yield stack stack_ids = list(nested_stack_ids(stack_id)) # count all resources which belong to the stacks ).filter( models.Resource.stack_id.in_(stack_ids) ).count()

commit_message:
Add resource.root_stack_id column

This change adds a root_stack_id column to the resource
record to allow a subsequent change enforce
max_resources_per_stack with a single query instead of the
many it currently requires.

This change includes the following:
- Data migration to add the resource.root_stack_id column
  and populate all existing resources with their calculated
  root stack
- Make new resources aquire and set their root_stack_id on
  store or update.
- StackResource._validate_nested_resources use the stored
  root_stack_id resulting in a ~15% performance improvement
  for the creation time of a test stack containing 40 nested
  stacks.

Change-Id: I2b00285514235834131222012408d2b5b2b37d30
Partial-Bug: 1489548
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/34/226134/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sqlalchemy def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) res_table = sqlalchemy.Table('resource', meta, autoload=True) stack_table = sqlalchemy.Table('stack', meta, autoload=True) root_stack_id = sqlalchemy.Column('root_stack_id', sqlalchemy.String(36)) root_stack_id.create(res_table) root_stack_idx = sqlalchemy.Index('ix_resource_root_stack_id', res_table.c.root_stack_id, mysql_length=36) root_stack_idx.create(migrate_engine) # build stack->owner relationship for all stacks stmt = sqlalchemy.select([stack_table.c.id, stack_table.c.owner_id]) stacks = migrate_engine.execute(stmt) parent_stacks = dict([(s.id, s.owner_id) for s in stacks]) def root_for_stack(stack_id): owner_id = parent_stacks.get(stack_id) if owner_id: return root_for_stack(owner_id) return stack_id # for each stack, update the resources with the root_stack_id for stack_id, owner_id in parent_stacks.items(): root_id = root_for_stack(stack_id) values = {'root_stack_id': root_id} update = res_table.update().where( res_table.c.stack_id == stack_id).values(values) migrate_engine.execute(update)

commit_message:
lib/nova: make redirects happen in correct order

It should redirect stdout to /dev/null firstly,
then redirect stderr to whatever stdout currently points at.

Change-Id: I4666fa90a96301f0b504a8501f0ffc3fe17616b0

commit_message:
Log message when debug is enabled

Operators may not realize that when debug is enabled that keystone
will return extra, potentially sensitive, data in error responses.

Operators should at least be warned that this will happen.

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I82d00898ee2b28aad1ace7554a436cf7125d631c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/10/226110/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Tempest: use mkdtemp to make temp directories

generate_random_name() was used instead of mkdtemp to create temporary
directories, with no check on existence. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I69c49e146ef1edca2b6fac0c0a9a06e158db160c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/69/222669/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch("tempfile.mkdtemp", return_value="fake_tempest_dir") mock_mkdtemp, directory = mock_mkdtemp.return_value dest = os.path.join(directory, fake_dir)
deleted_lines: @mock.patch("rally.common.utils.generate_random_name", return_value="fake_tempest_dir") mock_generate_random_name, subdir = mock_generate_random_name.return_value dest = os.path.join(self.base_repo_dir_patcher.new, subdir, fake_dir)

commit_message:
Raise container deployment timeout

If yum repository configuration is partially broken,
it will delay deployment time. The time should be
raised to match the dockerctl timeout of 400s.

Change-Id: Icc68f039362d7c3f08c532add14d24f2140b8e3d
Closes-Bug: #1494640

commit_message:
Add missing libvirt section to nova.conf

This is required to boot VMs using Nova. Add a sane default to the
template to suit most, and make it easier for those who want something
else to see where to override.

Change-Id: I898862b905289cc30ad447f0ef81895c93ff2478
Closes-Bug: #1496931

commit_message:
Use a EPEL mirror

Pin to a known good and fast EPEL mirror to aid reliability.

Change-Id: I3259413c1237b9f0db79e66afbdf8fb6d50520a1
Depends-On: Iefa22bde7a64b40e6d36ba39efa9102de9393e06

commit_message:
Enable back cover job

Rally 'cover' tox job runs against last two commits so, fix for
broken cover job was implemented with disabled job.
Now we need to enable it.

Change-Id: Id083b233ae072fa8e0a875dee74a33c6a3f51ec8
Partial-Bug: #1497897

commit_message:
Add option to set EPEL mirror

In some environments it may be desirable to set the EPEL
mirror to use. Add this ability.

Change-Id: Iefa22bde7a64b40e6d36ba39efa9102de9393e06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/21/225921/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [ -n "$DIB_EPEL_MIRROR" ] || exit 0 # Set the EPEL mirror to use sed -e "s|^#baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel|baseurl=$DIB_EPEL_MIRROR|;/^mirrorlist=/d" -i /etc/yum.repos.d/epel.repo

commit_message:
add ironic support:

 * Add new network 'ironic'
 * Add new role 'ironic_slave'. This VM looks like
   current 'slave' node, but it is connected ONLY
   to "ironic" network.
 * fix Node.interface_by_name method. Rename it to
   interface_by_network_name

Partially Implements: blueprint integrate-ironic-to-test-tools

Change-Id: Idd9ebca53c2cfd0df088c7d516f6285ad58fe7db

commit_message:
Parameter osapi_max_limit is always used by default

Default value max_limit is initialized before a value is read from
the config file. Default parameter values are always evaluated when
the def statement they belong to is executed. So parameter
osapi_max_limit is always used by default even it's set in the
configuration file.

Change-Id: I1414667d30e98b56c5eb1b09b802bab823b37e2d
Closes-Bug: #1487510

commit_message:
Using OpenStack CLI for supporting Keystone V3

Currently python-keystoneclient focuses on python API only and
python-openstackclient on CLI. This is certain trend now (ask from
keystone guys). So to enable more new features for example keystone v3
here, we need use openstackclient in devstack install scripts.

Notes:
python API means:
    # python scripts
    from keystoneclient import client as c
    c.Client(...).get_user_list(...)

CLI means:
    # bash/shell scripts
    keystone user-list

Closed-Bug: #1478763
Change-Id: Iee802c887994da7036fe206c1b2970c1006e273c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/92/206292/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ADMIN_USER=$(openstack user list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") ADMIN_ROLE=$(openstack role list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") BENHCMARK_TENANT=$(openstack project create benchmark \ openstack role add \ --user $ADMIN_USER \ --project $BENHCMARK_TENANT \ $ADMIN_ROLE
deleted_lines: ADMIN_USER=$(keystone user-list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") ADMIN_ROLE=$(keystone role-list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") BENHCMARK_TENANT=$(keystone tenant-create \ --name benchmark \ keystone user-role-add \ --user-id $ADMIN_USER \ --role-id $ADMIN_ROLE \ --tenant-id $BENHCMARK_TENANT

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-18 20:29:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/81a8c9f7ea0b7ec8626881e020224ae56a8f5f2c', 'message': "Relax service module check on service providers

commit_message:
Relax service module check on service providers

service_provider is a 'special' configuration. It is a MultiStr
option that used to be in neutron.conf, but moved into its own *-aas
config files after the service split. We allow for the definition to
be available 'anywhere': either in neutron.conf or in the *-aas
service's config file.

The list of 'service_provider' can include drivers from within the *-aas
tree, or from elsewhere, and can apply to different service types. Due to
the polymorphic nature of this variable it is very tricky to identify only
the drivers that pertain a specific service module: the service module
may as well implement more than one service type and may have support
from drivers out of tree.

For this reason it is best to relax this check and rely on query filters
when the ServiceManager.get_service_providers() is invoked. Furthermore,
without this fix there was a situation where the value returned by
'service_providers' may be differ depending on how the configuration is
passed on the CLI, and this inconsistency may only cause headaches.

Closes-bug: #1492069

Change-Id: I4db4ce0b287c984d86181227edf769531ecb7bb8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/22/225322/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Attempt to read the config from cfg.CONF first; when passing # --config-dir, the option is merged from all the definitions # made across all the imported config files try: providers = cfg.CONF.service_providers.service_provider # Alternatively, if the option is not available, try to load # it from the provider module's config file; this may be # necessary, if modules are loaded on the fly (DevStack may # be an example)
deleted_lines: # Attempt to read the config from cfg.CONF; this is possible # when passing --config-dir. Since the multiStr config option # gets merged, extract only the providers pertinent to this # service module. try: providers = [ sp for sp in cfg.CONF.service_providers.service_provider if self.module_name in sp ] # Alternatively, if the option is not avaialable, load the # config option using the module's built-in ini parser. # this may be necessary, if modules are loaded on the fly # (DevStack may be an example)

commit_message:
Switch config.mk to master branch for fuel projects

Due to bug[1] in Gerrit, 7.0-only patchset has been applied  to master. We
obviously want to track master in master branch

[1] https://code.google.com/p/gerrit/issues/detail?id=1107

Change-Id: I1c7a86711295bcb677db6778f57ab016ce53f149
Related-bug: #1466640

commit_message:
Add introductory documentation for networking-bgpvpn

This change includes README.rst directly into the base index.rst rather
than including it by reference in readme.rst and removes readme.rst from
the ToC. It also expands on the introductory paragraph in preparation for
linking to the top level index.html from the parent OpenStack developer
web page (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-projects.html)

Change-Id: Ifde5fa734fc1301c57598ec36d53895e94881588

commit_message:
Fix leaking environment variables in tests

In rspec provider tests the environment variables are used to
authenticate the calls.  The environment was set in a shared example.
The problem is that rspec read all those environment variables when it
compile the tests.  Then the last shared environment red by rspec was
setting the environment for all the test.  This was leading to
unpredictable behavior.

This fix this problem by setting the environment variables before each
test at rspec run time.

Change-Id: I28c952273d6f981c953cb3e2c960a98609ece263
Closes-Bug: 1482243

commit_message:
Get rid of ConfigParser code in ProviderConfiguration

We may be unable to get rid of this code, but at least we can
make it slimmer and more oslo_config friendly.

This patch also fixes an issue where plain ConfigParser cannot
handle config options with the same name under same section.

Related-bug: #1492069

Change-Id: I596613eb7b2fc3e894a3c1cc7b7cb24d7137cbc5

commit_message:
Update load balancers after HOT autoscaling event

This change adds the ability to update load balancers after an
autoscaling event is triggered on the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
resource in HOT templates. This feature is currently available only on
the AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup and OS::Heat::InstanceGroup
resources.

To implement this feature the following changes have been
made:

- Add "load_balancer_names" property to the OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
  resource, similar to "LoadBalancerNames" in InstanceGroup.
- Allow custom load balancer resources to be included in the
  "load_balancer_names" list. This is done so that regular instances
  running HAProxy or similar load balancers can also be updated after
  the ASG resizes. These custom resources are then able to get the
  updated list of instances through a get_attr call.

Closes-Bug: #1437524
Change-Id: Ib11f29e24e11fba93b59e39e5007f1b6c2814ec6

subject: Initial support for database clustering in Horizon

The Clusters Details will include the following tabs:
- Overview

'}, {'number': 27, 'created': '2015-04-17 14:41:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4d11208a06c3c5717996d6c02fa1e3b722b3ce57', 'message': 'Initial support for database clustering in Horizon

Added a separate panel for clusters.

This panel contains the Clusters Table with table actions to
Launch and Terminate clusters.  There are row actions Add Shard
and Reset Password (and their associated dialogs) that are specific
to MongoDB and Vertica respectively.

The Clusters Details will include the following tabs:
- Overview
- Instances (table of instances belonging to this cluster)

The launch panel has custom fields for MongoDB and Vertica.
The custom fields will be dynamically shown based on the datastore
selected.

Added a db_capability utility to aid in identifying the specific
datastores.

Co-Authored-By: Duk Loi <duk@tesora.com>
Co-Authored-By: Anna Shen <ruiyuan.shen@hp.com>
Change-Id: I047f4d37449070adfd0ea66ad010982f35c049aa
Implements: blueprint database-clustering-support

commit_message:
Initial support for database clustering in Horizon

Added a separate panel for clusters.

This panel contains the Clusters Table with table actions to
Launch and Terminate clusters.  There are row actions Add Shard
and Reset Password (and their associated dialogs) that are specific
to MongoDB and Vertica respectively.

The Clusters Details will include the following tabs:
- Overview
- Instances (table of instances belonging to this cluster)

The launch panel has custom fields for MongoDB and Vertica.
The custom fields will be dynamically shown based on the datastore
selected.

Added a db_capability utility to aid in identifying the specific
datastores.

Added network selection dropdown if neutron is enabled.

Co-Authored-By: Sushil Kumar <sushil.kumar3@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Saurabh Surana <saurabh.surana@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Duk Loi <duk@tesora.com>
Co-Authored-By: Anna Shen <ruiyuan.shen@hp.com>
Change-Id: I047f4d37449070adfd0ea66ad010982f35c049aa
Implements: blueprint database-clustering-support

commit_message:
Template-validate fails when resources are swaped with None resource

validate_template() in service.py is trying to validate the
properties mentioned in the template using the Resource plugin
class. This fails as None resource plugin properties are always
empty.

Fix is added to skip the NoneResource validation appropriately.
TemplateResource also made adhere to same logic.

Change-Id: I3e9e0ee69b863c1cadcff78eed822e3c3a75fbf6
Closes-Bug: #1495914

commit_message:
WiP Only get host data for floating ips on DVR routers

First, we should only be interested in setting the host
attributed whet the router is a DVR router (this may need to be
vetted).  Second, we don't need to query all of the ports on the host,
we just need to query the ports that are referenced by the set of
floating ips that we already have.

Don't merge this.  The original patch has not been merged yet.

Signed-off-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>
Closes-bug: #1496974
(cherry picked from commit 3999409b8c07f7cca9a27fd53aa8ca81cfa64028)

Change-Id: I955a10e135bba9011e68ec6b26d27d82ab2d3410

commit_message:
Add a functional test proving OS::Heat::None works with validate

Previously the template-validate logic failed when overriding
resources with OS::Heat::None in the resource_registry, despite
this working fine via create/preview.

Since the fix for bug #1467573 has aligned the template-validate
logic with that of create/preview, this should now work.

Change-Id: Id8d0be57d347e7ef6714477747949bd2dadd470c
Closes-Bug: #1495914
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/63/225263/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_template_validate_override_none(self): env = {'resource_registry': { 'OS::Heat::RandomString': 'OS::Heat::None'}} ret = self.client.stacks.validate(template=self.random_template, environment=env) expected = {'Description': 'the stack description', 'Parameters': { 'aparam': {'Default': 10, 'Description': 'the param description', 'Label': 'aparam', 'NoEcho': 'false', 'Type': 'Number'}}} self.assertEqual(expected, ret)

commit_message:
Migrate to Kubernetes Release 1

Kubernetes Release 1.0 was announced at OSCON

A new Fedora Atomic image has been built with version 1.0.4 and
this series of patches will update the templates, scripts, documents
to work with the new image.

The api has also been changed from v1beta3 to v1 and the beta
api is no longer available, so the interface between Magnum and
Kubernetes master are updated as well in this series of patches.

This particular patch will bring up a V1 cluster with the
bay-create command.  Because the switch to the V1 API requires
all the code changes to be applied at once, this patch pulls
in portion of 3 patches together.  The changes include:

1. devstack plugin downloads the new image.

2. k8s conductor and other code calls the new V1 client and
k8s methods.

3. Configuration for k8s services and docker updated with
new parameters.

4. Minion registration and example code updated to V1.

5. Functional tests updated to V1.

6. Gate test setup points to the new image.

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin.lu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I046931ad491e8b7ee45943852901eac5c3df913e
Partially-Implements: blueprint kubernetes-v1

commit_message:
test_dashboard_basic_ops: handle urllib2 exceptions in check_login_page

The first HTTP request is done by check_login_page.
This patch aims to try the request and handle exceptions to define
why a request would fail, by giving message and http return code.

Change-Id: If38b5d7e9dd47af87d0b678eac0506243361e852
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/53/226153/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: response = request.urlopen(CONF.dashboard.dashboard_url) except requests.HTTPError as e: if hasattr(e, 'reason'): print 'The request failed to reach the server.' print 'Reason: ', e.reason elif hasattr(e, 'code'): print 'The server couldn\'t fulfill the request.' print 'Error code: ', e.code else: self.assertIn("id_username", response.read())

commit_message:
enhance nova list output with new three fields

Nova list to accept a new parameter --maximal.
Using --maximal option we can have three new fields.
These three new files are
flavor-name
availability-zone-list
image-name

Change-Id: Idf55af5999a323996c7e5f1581901ab4a4174eed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/96/216096/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Enhance nova list output with three new fields ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-novaclient/+spec/enhance-nova-list-output Nova list will accept a new optional parameter --maximal. Using --maximal option we can have three new fields. Following are three new fields are * flavor-name * availability-zone * image-name Problem description =================== Currently we have 'nova-list' CLI command to list active servers with fields ID, Name, Status, Task State, Power State and Networks. 'nova-list' command has a number of optional parameters out of which --minimal is one option. nova-list --minimal command displays only UUID and name of servers. To enhance the output of nova-list we can have a --maximal optional parameter. By this option user will have 3 more new columns added to existing columns. With these three new columns user will get image, flavor and availability zone details. Use Cases ---------- This is purely to enhance the output of nova list with additional parameters which are not shown by other optional parameters. Project Priority ----------------- None. Proposed change =============== An additional optional parameter --maximal is to be added to the existing nova -list optional parameters. When 'nova-list --maximal' command is given, it outputs the server list. This server list has details with fields ID, Name, Status, Task State, Power State, Networks along-with ( new additional fields i.e ) flavor-name, availability-zone and image-name. There will be no change in behavior for request except for the additional fields. Python novaclient/v2/shell.py has to be updated with the additional parameter and new fields to be listed during nova-list --maximal. For images, we get the image id only. So to get image name we need to use glance api to get image name. For flavors, we get the flavor id only. So to get flavor name we need to call nova flavor api to get flavor name. For availability, we get the values from nova server api call itself. Alternatives ------------ Through nova show command we can get the details i.e. image, flavor and availability zone for single server. Through horizon, we can get these details i.e. image, flavor and availability zone in instances table. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rsritesh Other contributors: Divya Work Items ---------- * Add --maximal parameter with necessary code in @cliutils module in shell.py * Add corresponding column fields to the above * Call glance api and nova flavor api to the names * Update novaclient with necessary changes Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit test cases will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== In Compute command-line client document, nova-list would accomodate the --maximal parameter. References ========== None. History ======= None.

commit_message:
Validates baymodel network_driver requests

Instead of allowing any network_driver value to be accepted by
the baymodel API, this patch limits the value to "flannel". As
additional network drivers get merged, the validation will be
expanded.

Co-Authored-By: Dane LeBlanc <leblancd@cisco.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint extend-baymodel-net-attributes

Change-Id: I62397f30d08d3d684285cdc9d94a6f5b7d509940
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/37/222337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def enforce_network_driver_types(*network_driver_types): @decorator.decorator def wrapper(func, *args, **kwargs): obj = args[1] bay = objects.Bay.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, obj.bay_uuid) baymodel = objects.BayModel.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, bay.baymodel_id) if baymodel.network_driver not in network_driver_types: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue( 'Cannot fulfill request with a ' '%(network_driver_type)s network_driver, ' 'expecting a %(supported_network_driver_types)s ' 'network_driver.' % {'network_driver_type': baymodel.network_driver, 'supported_network_driver_types': '/' .join(network_driver_types)}) return func(*args, **kwargs) return wrapper

subject: Add DB2 support
revisions:
[{'number': 13, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1c8b1caff7964d329a21ffd19f181fbb3713763b', 'message': 'Add DB2 support

General: I've made this one big patch rather than several patches
in a series because the thinking is we're either going to merge
all of the DB2 support together or none of it at all. This also
helps with the 3rd party CI testing so it can just run tests on
this patch until the code is merged. I've outlined the details below
for reviewing the change.

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. The lack
   of foreign keys has not presented any functional issues. A possible
   solution is a future patch which makes the instances.uuid column
   non-nullable but that presents it's own difficulties and is outside
   the scope of this change.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Other changes:

1. Handle the 'ibm_db_sa' sqlalchemy engine in the modify_indexes
   utility method.

2. Sync commit 8dccc7b "Handle ibm_db_sa DBDuplicateEntry integrity
   errors" from oslo-incubator. This is needed for 3rd party CI to pass
   for DB2 against Tempest negative tests that rely on duplicate entries
   failing and being handled in the DB API layer. This is not a full
   of the oslo db module since:
   (a) that would pull in far more than is needed here
   (b) oslo db hasn't been synced to Nova since July of 2013 so it would
       not be trivial
   (c) Mirantis is already working on syncing oslo db to Nova but it
       will probably be awhile before that lands.

Implements blueprint db2-database
Closes-Bug: #1227321

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a31b9407910cae75ee3f0db417337aafd80b8a41', 'message': 'Add DB2 support

General: I've made this one big patch rather than several patches
in a series because the thinking is we're either going to merge
all of the DB2 support together or none of it at all. This also
helps with the 3rd party CI testing so it can just run tests on
this patch until the code is merged. I've outlined the details below
for reviewing the change.

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column.
   TODO(mriedem): resolve what to do about this, either make
   instances.uuid.nullable=False in the DB2 case or add a migration
   that does it for all engines but this is much more complicated,
   see the ML thread on the topic:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-March/029467.html

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f78776b59edfc68fa8bfbc8cc8b773eeb42fb187', 'message': 'Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. The lack
   of foreign keys has not presented any functional issues. A possible
   solution is a future patch which makes the instances.uuid column
   non-nullable but that presents it's own difficulties and is outside
   the scope of this change.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Other changes:

1. Handle the 'ibm_db_sa' sqlalchemy engine in the modify_indexes
utility
   method.

2. Sync commit 8dccc7b "Handle ibm_db_sa DBDuplicateEntry integrity
   errors" from oslo-incubator. This is needed for 3rd party CI to pass
   for DB2 against Tempest negative tests that rely on duplicate entries
   failing and being handled in the DB API layer. This is not a full
   of the oslo db module since:
   (a) that would pull in far more than is needed here
   (b) oslo db hasn't been synced to Nova since July of 2013 so it would
       not be trivial
   (c) Mirantis is already working on syncing oslo db to Nova but it
will
       probably be awhile before that lands.

Implements blueprint db2-database
Closes-Bug: #1227321

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

'}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/580cc4dc52fc3895a69b0eb06baa89772b909db4', 'message': "WIP: Add DB2 support

General: I've made this one big patch rather than several patches
in a series because the thinking is we're either going to merge
all of the DB2 support together or none of it at all. This also
helps with the 3rd party CI testing so it can just run tests on
this patch until the code is merged. I've outlined the details below
for reviewing the change.

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid I've added migration 245 to drop
   any records where instances.uuid == None (and related tables where
   instance_uuid == None, except for fixed_ips - details inline) so we
   can make instances.uuid non-nullable and create a unique constraint
   on instances.uuid, then new migration 246 creates the missing
   instances.uuid related foreign keys for DB2. There was some mailing
   list discussion about making instances.uuid non-nullable and is
   further discussed in the related nova-spec.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit

   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration 246 here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration 247 here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. The ibm_db_sa DB URI in test_migrations.conf is non-standard due to
   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

   how it must be formed to work with the IBM DB2 ODBC/CLI driver.

3. TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR is bumped since the scaling factor of 2 wasn't
   keeping up with the tests on an m1.medium instance used for testing.

4. Schemas are used rather than databases for the tests since the
   create/drop of those are significantly faster in DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then

"}, {'number': 37, 'created': '2014-12-15 22:34:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c705cd7d923e3d3b5056fdaa4cbf5809733ab3c5', 'message': "Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f
"}, {'number': 38, 'created': '2015-01-08 22:37:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d7b056efc7e29a59549f0754a34e5f1d78e134d3', 'message': "WIP: Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 269 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the

"}, {'number': 41, 'created': '2015-01-31 01:43:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fe43b9ea33bb684835b9fd929d41242873f365e0', 'message': "Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).
   There is a foreign key involved (created in 246) so for DB2 to
   have the same FKey it requires a UC and that requires the deleted
   column to be non-null, which doesn't work with the SoftDeleteMixin.
   So in this case the schema will diverge for DB2 until we make
   the deleted column non-nullable for all tables.

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 273 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

"}, {'number': 43, 'created': '2015-02-16 22:39:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/12216bfdc4b41d13c84c887016c76c6e36e7c8c8', 'message': "Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2015.2 'L' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).
   There is a foreign key involved (created in 246) so for DB2 to
   have the same FKey it requires a UC and that requires the deleted
   column to be non-null, which doesn't work with the SoftDeleteMixin.
   So in this case the schema will diverge for DB2 until we make
   the deleted column non-nullable for all tables.

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 277 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f

commit_message:
Add DB2 support

Notes on migration changes/tests:

1. The initial havana migration does not create any foreign keys which
   require the instances.uuid column since it's nullable and DB2 won't
   allow creating a unique constraint over a nullable column. To create
   the foreign keys on instances.uuid, this change depends on commit
   e07a2b2d4be0503ad8dad75daa632be27cf83320 to make instances.uuid
   non-nullable and create a unique constraint on that column. Then
   the new migration here creates the missing instances.uuid
   related foreign keys for DB2.

2. Commit b930fb3a6b0ab8cbe0c19eb3ab8ba33d60d147be changed
   test_migrations.py to use oslo.db's opportunistic test fixture
   which currently only supports sqlite/mysql/postgresql. Unit test
   support for DB2 therefore needs to be added to oslo.db and then
   hooked into nova, but that's targeted for the 2016.1 'M' release
   so is not part of this change.

3. The 247_nullable_mismatch migration is updated for DB2 because
   making the pci_devices.deleted column nullable=True fails since
   the column is in a UniqueConstraint already (DB2 would require
   it to be in a unique index instead for the column to be nullable).
   There is a foreign key involved (created in 246) so for DB2 to
   have the same FKey it requires a UC and that requires the deleted
   column to be non-null, which doesn't work with the SoftDeleteMixin.
   So in this case the schema will diverge for DB2 until we make
   the deleted column non-nullable for all tables.

4. The 252_add_instance_extra_table migration is updated for DB2
   because a foreign key is created between the instance_extra
   table and the instances.uuid column (which is nullable at the
   time) so we have to handle that foreign key constraint creation
   in the 296 migration with the other foreign keys to
   instances.uuid.

5. The 271 migration is updated to add ibm_db_sa the same as
   sqlite and postgresql since it works the same in this case for
   DB2.

6. The API migrations need checks for DB2 to avoid a duplicate index
   SQL0605W error since DB2 implicitly creates an Index when a
   UniqueConstraint is created and will fail if trying to add a
   duplicate index on the same column(s) that are in the UC.

Implements blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: Ic4224e2545bcdfeb236b071642f9f16d9ee3b99f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/69047/45 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _have_db2(connect_uri): present = os.environ.get('NOVA_TEST_DB2_PRESENT') if present is None: try: engine = sqlalchemy.create_engine(connect_uri) connection = engine.connect() except Exception: # intentionally catch all to handle exceptions even if we don't # have any backend code loaded. return False else: connection.close() engine.dispose() return True return present.lower() in ('', 'true') def get_db2_connection_info(conn_pieces): """ Pulls information out of the parsed DB2 connection string. Assumes a local database. :returns: tuple of (user, password, database, schema) """ database = conn_pieces.path.split('@')[1].split('=')[1] # Convert the params to a dict so we can get user/password/schema params = dict((k.strip(), v.strip()) for k, v in (item.split('=') for item in conn_pieces.params.split(';'))) return (params['UID'], params['PWD'], database, params['CurrentSchema']) def test_db2_opportunistically(self): self._test_db2_opportunistically() def test_db2_connect_fail(self): """ Test that we can trigger a DB2 connection failure and we fail gracefully to ensure we don't break people without DB2. """ if _is_backend_avail('ibm_db_sa', "openstack_cifail", self.PASSWD, self.DATABASE): self.fail("Shouldn't have connected") TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR = 3 def execute_cmd(self, cmd=None, check_exit_code=[0]): out, err = processutils.trycmd(cmd, shell=True, discard_warnings=True, check_exit_code=check_exit_code) def _does_db2_schema_exist(self, user, database, schema): LOG.info("Checking for schema '%(schema)s' in " "database '%(database)s'." % {'schema': schema, 'database': database}) cmd = ('su - %(user)s -c "db2 \'connect to %(database)s\'; ' 'db2 \\"select create_time from syscat.schemata where ' 'schemaname=\'%(schema)s\'\\""' % {'user': user, 'database': database, 'schema': schema.upper()}) # 0 means it does exist # 1 means it doesn't exist (returned 0 rows from query) try: self.execute_cmd(cmd) return True except AssertionError: return False @utils.synchronized('db2', external=True) def _reset_db2(self, conn_pieces): (user, password, database, schema) = \ get_db2_connection_info(conn_pieces) if self._does_db2_schema_exist(user, database, schema): # NOTE(mriedem): We use an admin command to drop the schema # and everything in it. connect_cmd = 'db2 \'CONNECT TO %s\'' % database drop_schema_cmd = ( 'db2 \\"CALL SYSPROC.ADMIN_DROP_SCHEMA' '(\'%s\', NULL, \'ERRORSCHEMA\', \'ERRORTABLE\')\\"' % # NOTE(mriedem): The schema has to be in uppercase schema.upper() ) drop_errortable_cmd = 'db2 \"DROP TABLE ERRORSCHEMA.ERRORTABLE\"' cmd = ('su - %(user)s -c "%(connect_cmd)s; %(drop_schema_cmd)s"' % {'user': user, 'connect_cmd': connect_cmd, 'drop_schema_cmd': drop_schema_cmd}) LOG.info("Dropping DB2 %(database)s.%(schema)s." % {'schema': schema, 'database': database}) self.execute_cmd(cmd) elif conn_string.startswith('ibm_db_sa'): self._create_database_db2(conn_pieces) def _create_database_db2(self, conn_pieces): (user, password, database, schema) = \ get_db2_connection_info(conn_pieces) # TODO(mriedem): Check if the database exists and create it if not. cmd = ('su - %(user)s -c "' 'db2 \'connect to %(database)s\'; ' 'db2 \'create schema %(schema)s\'"' % {'user': user, 'database': database, 'schema': schema}) LOG.info("Creating DB2 schema %(database)s.%(schema)s" % {'schema': schema, 'database': database}) # 0 means schema is created # 4 means it already exists (which is fine) # otherwise raise an error # The actual DB2 SQL error code is SQL0601N self.execute_cmd(cmd, check_exit_code=[0, 4]) elif conn_string.startswith('ibm_db_sa'): self._reset_db2(conn_pieces) def _test_db2_opportunistically(self): # Test DB2 database migration walk if 'ibm_db_sa' not in self.test_databases: self.skipTest("DB2 (ibm_db_sa) not configured") connect_string = self.test_databases['ibm_db_sa'] if not _have_db2(connect_string): self.skipTest("DB2 (ibm_db_sa) not available") engine = sqlalchemy.create_engine(connect_string) (user, password, database, schema) = \ get_db2_connection_info(urlparse.urlparse(connect_string)) self.engines[schema] = engine self.test_databases[schema] = connect_string # build a fully populated db2 database with all the tables self._reset_database(schema) self._walk_versions(engine, self.snake_walk, self.downgrade) del(self.engines[schema]) del(self.test_databases[schema])
deleted_lines: TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR = 2 def execute_cmd(self, cmd=None): out, err = processutils.trycmd(cmd, shell=True, discard_warnings=True)

commit_message:
Use normal API not token/endpoint for image uploads

There is no reason to use keystone token bootstrapping for image
uploads. Glance is a service, and images can be uploaded to it normally
without special shenanigans.

Depends-On: If7b81c4a6746c8a1eb0302c96e045fb0f457d67b
Change-Id: I7092fb10cbe243e091789134263fab081af0c7f4

commit_message:
Move writing of credentials earlier in the process

If something goes wrong after keystone is running with services
registered, but before credentials are written, it's hard to poke at the
existing half-running state because none of the auth information is
recorded.

Write the files right after we're done bootstrapping keystone.

Change-Id: I2f8ae86e17d26ec4defa16e843faa8987d27fac9

added_lines: # We now have a working keystone. From this point, everything can be done # with normal auth. Let's write out the auth config files so that if something # goes wrong subsequently, developers debugging have stackrc and clouds.yaml # files to use to poke at things # Create account rc files # ======================= # Creates source able script files for easier user switching. # This step also creates certificates for tenants and users, # which is helpful in image bundle steps. if is_service_enabled nova && is_service_enabled keystone; then USERRC_PARAMS="-PA --target-dir $TOP_DIR/accrc" if [ -f $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE ]; then USERRC_PARAMS="$USERRC_PARAMS --os-cacert $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE" fi if [[ "$HEAT_STANDALONE" = "True" ]]; then USERRC_PARAMS="$USERRC_PARAMS --heat-url http://$HEAT_API_HOST:$HEAT_API_PORT/v1" fi $TOP_DIR/tools/create_userrc.sh $USERRC_PARAMS fi # Save some values we generated for later use save_stackenv # Update/create user clouds.yaml file. # clouds.yaml will have # - A `devstack` entry for the `demo` user for the `demo` project. # - A `devstack-admin` entry for the `admin` user for the `admin` project. # The location is a variable to allow for easier refactoring later to make it # overridable. There is currently no usecase where doing so makes sense, so # it's not currently configurable. CLOUDS_YAML=~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml mkdir -p $(dirname $CLOUDS_YAML) CA_CERT_ARG='' if [ -f "$SSL_BUNDLE_FILE" ]; then CA_CERT_ARG="--os-cacert $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE" fi $TOP_DIR/tools/update_clouds_yaml.py \ --file $CLOUDS_YAML \ --os-cloud devstack \ --os-region-name $REGION_NAME \ --os-identity-api-version $IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ $CA_CERT_ARG \ --os-auth-url $KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v$IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ --os-username demo \ --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD \ --os-project-name demo $TOP_DIR/tools/update_clouds_yaml.py \ --file $CLOUDS_YAML \ --os-cloud devstack-admin \ --os-region-name $REGION_NAME \ --os-identity-api-version $IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ $CA_CERT_ARG \ --os-auth-url $KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v$IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ --os-username admin \ --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD \ --os-project-name admin

There is currently no usecase where doing so makes sense, so # it's not currently configurable. CLOUDS_YAML=~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml mkdir -p $(dirname $CLOUDS_YAML) CA_CERT_ARG='' if [ -f "$SSL_BUNDLE_FILE" ]; then CA_CERT_ARG="--os-cacert $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE" fi $TOP_DIR/tools/update_clouds_yaml.py \ --file $CLOUDS_YAML \ --os-cloud devstack \ --os-region-name $REGION_NAME \ --os-identity-api-version $IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ $CA_CERT_ARG \ --os-auth-url $KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v$IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ --os-username demo \ --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD \ --os-project-name demo $TOP_DIR/tools/update_clouds_yaml.py \ --file $CLOUDS_YAML \ --os-cloud devstack-admin \ --os-region-name $REGION_NAME \ --os-identity-api-version $IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ $CA_CERT_ARG \ --os-auth-url $KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v$IDENTITY_API_VERSION \ --os-username admin \ --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD \ --os-project-name admin

commit_message:
Prevent extraneous log messages and stdout prints

while running unit tests using run_tests.sh,
we can see quite an amount of unwanted log
messages and stdout prints as part of
the unit test results on the console.
This basically makes it difficult to go
through the test results and figure whats happening.

This patch fixes the cause for those
extraneous log messages caused due to
a incorrect fixture usage in test_manage.py
and also by mocking sys.stdout at the respective unit tests.

Closes-bug: #1496898
Change-Id: If986691cb3f36ba357a5c0df34b6df7bf2d8ff86

commit_message:
Fixed an HTTP 500 on artifact blob upload

If the HTTP PUT request to upload a binary file to an artifact does not
contain a Content-size header, the length of the binary file should be
detected during the upload.

However, the unset content size variable was leading to an exception as
its value (None) participates in some math operations during the upload.
Setting the value to 0 (same is v2 API) fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1488037
FastTrack

Change-Id: Iadbd97899445b58c2c5bad961bca61cd6ab60d1a

commit_message:
Add documentation for configuring IdP WebSSO

We recently added a new federation call to Keystone that will allow federated
authentication flows for a specific Identity Provider. This commit adds
documentation around configuring httpd modules for the newly added call and
horizon configuration.

Co-Authored-By: Lin Hua Cheng <os.lcheng@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Id334e979c951387b1d70da70fc5d4939a6e7d6a6
related: bp federation-idp-websso
Closes-Bug: 1491910
Related-Bug: 1491916

added_lines: The `/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/websso/<protocol>` and `/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/{idp_id}/protocols/{protocol_id}/websso` routes must be protected by the chosen httpd module. This is performed so the request that originates from horizon will use the same identity provider that is configured in keystone. .. NOTE:: It is important to remember that misconfiguration of httpd modules may expose security vulnerabilities in a Federated deployment. <Location ~ "/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/idp_1/protocols/saml2/websso"> AuthType shibboleth Require valid-user ... </Location> OIDCRedirectURI http://localhost:5000/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/idp_1/protocol/oidc/websso/redirect <Location ~ "/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/idp_1/protocols/oidc/websso"> AuthType openid-connect Require valid-user ... </Location> <Location ~ "/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/idp_1/protocols/kerberos/websso"> AuthType Kerberos AuthName "Acme Corporation" KrbMethodNegotiate on KrbMethodK5Passwd off Krb5Keytab /etc/apache2/http.keytab ... </Location> <Location ~ "/v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/idp_1/protocols/saml2/websso"> AuthType Mellon MellonEnable auth Require valid-user ... </Location>
