commit_message:
Skip nodes that does not support REPLICATE verb

Alternative DiskFile backend implementations may not support or
implement REPLICATE verb. This change allows object replicator to
recognize such object servers and "black list" them and not send
further REPLICATE requests. This "black list" is cleared at
beginning of every replicator pass. Hence, each object server that
does not support REPLICATE verb will at the most be contacted once per
pass.

This change assumes that DiskFile implementations return
HTTPNotImplemented (501).

Change-Id: I267808be88a025aaa8ce05ba63c15169ac18df9e
Signed-off-by: Prashanth Pai <ppai@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/15/149315/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from swift.common.http import HTTP_OK, HTTP_INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE, \ HTTP_NOT_IMPLEMENTED, HTTP_METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED # Set of nodes that does not support REPLICATE verb # Each element of the set is a tuple (replication_ip, replication_port) self.nodes_without_replicate = set() if (node['replication_ip'], node['replication_port']) in \ self.nodes_without_replicate: # Skip nodes that are known to not handle REPLICATE verb. continue if resp.status in \ (HTTP_NOT_IMPLEMENTED, HTTP_METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED): self.logger.info(_('%(ip)s/%(device)s does not' ' support REPLICATE verb'), node) # Track nodes that cannot handle REPLICATE verb # And do not send further requests to them. self.nodes_without_replicate.add(( node['replication_ip'], node['replication_port'])) continue self.nodes_without_replicate.clear()

commit_message:
Fixed non-owner write-access to artifacts

There was no check for write-access priviledges during all the
mutating operations with artifacts (updates, patches, deletes,
actiovations etc), so any user who has an access to an artifact could
modify it. Because of this, non-owners could modify public artifacts
which was a major security issue.

Now this is addressed and an appropriate set of tests added to
prevent possible regressions.

FastTrack
Change-Id: I2f4c2d70b74ae39ababed2ba9b97559ef5ea6d6c
Closes-bug: #1489902

commit_message:
tests: don't validate respawn as part of ovsdb monitor functional test

It's already validated by AsyncProcess functional test suite. Instead,
just validate that the monitor generates the initial output, as
expected.

The test is still useful to validate that rootwrap filter works, so
not removing it completely.

Change-Id: I320edaaa2b210e4b34678c60deb31c4875eea298
Closes-Bug: #1495937

commit_message:
ovsdb monitor: get rid of custom _read_stdout/_read_stderr methods

Those methods do the same thing as AsyncProcess counterparts, just
with logging the received output. It's better to move the logging into
AsyncProcess and control it with __init__ arguments.

This allows us to get rid of some duplicate tests for ovsdb monitor.

Change-Id: Ic20ded27ba09afdd73e4d96c47469c2d7b4d4db5
Related-Bug: #1495937
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/28/224728/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test___init__(self): ovsdb_monitor.OvsdbMonitor('Interface') def test___init___with_columns(self): columns = ['col1', 'col2'] with mock.patch( 'neutron.agent.linux.async_process.AsyncProcess.__init__') as init: ovsdb_monitor.OvsdbMonitor('Interface', columns=columns) cmd = init.call_args_list[0][0][0] self.assertEqual('col1,col2', cmd[-1]) def test___init___with_format(self): with mock.patch( 'neutron.agent.linux.async_process.AsyncProcess.__init__') as init: ovsdb_monitor.OvsdbMonitor('Interface', format='blob') cmd = init.call_args_list[0][0][0] self.assertEqual('--format=blob', cmd[-1])
deleted_lines: def setUp(self): super(TestOvsdbMonitor, self).setUp() self.monitor = ovsdb_monitor.OvsdbMonitor('Interface') def read_output_queues_and_returns_result(self, output_type, output): with mock.patch.object(self.monitor, '_process') as mock_process: with mock.patch.object(mock_process, output_type) as mock_file: with mock.patch.object(mock_file, 'readline') as mock_readline: mock_readline.return_value = output func = getattr(self.monitor, '_read_%s' % output_type, None) return func() def test__read_stdout_returns_none_for_empty_read(self): result = self.read_output_queues_and_returns_result('stdout', '') self.assertIsNone(result) def test__read_stdout_queues_normal_output_to_stdout_queue(self): output = 'foo' result = self.read_output_queues_and_returns_result('stdout', output) self.assertEqual(result, output) self.assertEqual(self.monitor._stdout_lines.get_nowait(), output) def test__read_stderr_returns_none(self): result = self.read_output_queues_and_returns_result('stderr', '') self.assertIsNone(result)

subject: Add neutron_migrations_facts module
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-02 16:03:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/c6fbc99cb444429b54e63c83000ed15338e9c1e2', 'message': "[WIP] Remove unnecessary tasks in neutron_db_setup.yml

Doing the initial check for existing migrations is pointless -- we can
just run the same DB upgrade tasks irrespective of whether or not we've
already run an upgrade.  Note that this change does replace
neutron_db_revision user variable with neutron_db_expand_revision and
neutron_db_contract_revision since specifying just neutron_db_revision
isn't optimal when we have two branches and can run migrations on each
branch individually.

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-09-10 10:20:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/2539ab9f7fbbab56d891fcd8d6acf7b04e10b63a', 'message': "More changes to neutron db migrations

This change does the following:

1. Adds user variables and neutron_db_expand_revision and
   neutron_db_contract_revision to replace neutron_db_revision (this is
   necessary since we now have two alembic branches, not one)
2. Runs the initial neutron-db-manage current without grep'ing so we
   can fail if that does not return an exit code of 0 (this is safer,
   as previously an exit code of 1 would go undetected due to the piped
   grep)
3. Updates the grep on the stdout from above to be more precise; neutron
   revision IDs seem to have a lenght ranging from 4 to 12
4. Changes the initial db sync to just doing --expand, which can be
   done whether or not migrations have previously run (this also
   removes the hard-coded reference to 'heads', which may have had
   unintended side-effects if someone specified a different revision)
5. Changes all neutron-db-manage upgrade tasks to use the specified
   revision

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head instead.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-09-10 12:00:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/8a73999a94f4094d7d6fbbffb7734bc72012a63c', 'message': "More changes to neutron db migrations

This change does the following:

1. Adds user variables and neutron_db_expand_revision and
   neutron_db_contract_revision to replace neutron_db_revision (this is
   necessary since we now have two alembic branches, not one)
2. Runs the initial neutron-db-manage current without grep'ing so we
   can fail if that does not return an exit code of 0 (this is safer,
   as previously an exit code of 1 would go undetected due to the piped
   grep)
3. Creates a new task to parse the output of the above and sets a fact
   if a match is found (this indicates migrations have previously run)
4. Removes the initial db sync task since this is no longer needed
5. Updates the expand task to use the specified revision and runs it
   regardless of whether or not migrations have already been run
6. Similar to above, contract now uses the specified revision and also
   runs regardless, however guards are in place to only stop/start
   neutron-server on a brownfield deploy (doing this on a greenfield
   deploy will fail since the neutron-server service hasn't been
   fully configured/started)

If there is no value in allowing the DB revision to be specified,
please let me know and I'll just hardcode to head instead.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1486593
Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

commit_message:
Add neutron_migrations_facts module

This change does the following:

1. Adds neutron_migrations_facts module, which creates a fact
   with the state of each neutron alembic migration branch
2. Removes var neutron_db_revision since this is no longer used
3. Removes the migration check task since this is now handled by the
   neutron_migrations_facts module
4. Updates roles/os_neutron/tasks/main.yml so the init scripts are
   dropped before we handle db syncing, which means we can stop the
   neutron-server on a greenfield deploy

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie0c5cb5abff61d11b7a9278de6771fa008b69218

files, so ignore-errors now produces an error where it did not
before.

commit_message:
WIP - add some tags describing roles

This is a rough initial draft, adding four new tags along two axis.
I fully expect that it will be met with some disagreement, and would
like a discussion around both what is wrong and what is missing from
this proposal.

Covering some of the existing service projects' intended usage,
these two tags describe where in the stack an OpenStack service
fits:
- role:base-compute-ring
- role:cloud-native-application

Covering the intended consumer of user-facing projects, these two tags
describe whether the project targets cloud operators or cloud
application developers.
- role:user-interface
- role:operator-interface

Neither of the above axis are completely covered in the current
proposal. Eg, none of these tags would apply to swift, ironic, or
devstack.

Change-Id: I68955d0122884d3d351193347ca8d61410c232cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/36/163236/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== role:user-interface =================== This tag is part of the "role" category of tags, describing the intended role or use-case that the project serves within the OpenStack ecosystem. Some projects provide services that can reasonably be expected from any cloud, while others provide additional capability on top of the platform. Similarly, some projects are developed for a particular audience, while other projects may be more generally applicable. Projects with the "role:user-interface" tag are intended to be consumed or utilized directly by end-users of a cloud. This includes clients, libraries, and graphical user interfaces. Rationale ========= The number of projects in the OpenStack ecosystem is significant, and determining which projects are suitable for a given use-case is already challenging for newcomers. By grouping projects around common use cases, we can help users identify projects that address their needs. Requirements ============ * "role:user-interface" projects must have as their intended audience the end-users of OpenStack services. Tag application process ======================= This tag should be voluntarily applied by a project's PTL, if the projects mission is to provide users with tools to interact with OpenStack services. Since it is voluntarily applied and descriptive, approval does not require a vote by the TC. Deprecation =========== Tags in the "role" category describe the intent of the project. If the project changes direction, the tag should be updated, but references should be maintained to prior releases' tags, as long as those releases are supported by the project or stable-maintenance teams. Attributes ========== Tags in the "role" category do not use attributes. Application to current projects =============================== As application of this tag is voluntary, it should not be applied to any projects initially. However, were it to be applied today, it would apply, at a minimum, to Horizon and python-openstackclient. Whether or not it would apply to other python-\*client projects is debatable.

subject: Only write to template files if template data changes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-18 00:13:41.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/template_resource.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/779ba8e431aecac3c451c08aedcc0ad8cf0a4449', 'message': 'Only write to template files if template data changes

Currently the template data is assigned to the files dict regardless
of whether the data has changed or not.

This has no consequence on Liberty, but the files dict in Kilo
and Juno is a sqlalchemy MutableDict so these assignments are triggering
updates to the raw_template table. These updates are even triggered for
calls to heat resource-list. With large raw_template records this can make
heat unusable.

Therefore this fix is presented here as having no effect (and being
harmless) to git master, but high priority backports for Kilo and Juno.

Change-Id: Ibb714a9c5dc9f6879ff108419127da985a57897b
Closes-Bug: #1494108
'}]
commit_message:
Only write to template files if template data changes

Currently the template data is assigned to the files dict regardless
of whether the data has changed or not.

This has no consequence on Liberty, but the files dict in Kilo
and Juno is a sqlalchemy MutableDict so these assignments are triggering
updates to the raw_template table. These updates are even triggered for
calls to heat resource-list. With large raw_template records this can make
heat unusable.

Therefore this fix is presented here as having no effect (and being
harmless) to git master, but high priority backports for Kilo and Juno.

Change-Id: Ibb714a9c5dc9f6879ff108419127da985a57897b
Closes-Bug: #1494108

commit_message:
diskfile: make get_ondisk_files return a dict

get_ondisk_files gathers a dict with more info than just the set
of data, ts and/or meta files, but only returns the
set of files to the DiskFile class. The other info
in the dict may be useful policy specific implementations, so
return the whole dict.

Also, refactor _get_ondisk_file to move duplicated code into the
BaseDiskFile open() method.

Change-Id: I7a17d26b7ed7f7c593f577332937793419c03cfa
Co-Authored-By: Paul Luse <paul.e.luse@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/06/222706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from operator import itemgetter :returns: dict of files to use having keys 'data_file', 'ts_file', 'meta_file' and optionally other policy specific keys file_info = self.gather_ondisk_files(files, verify=True, **kwargs) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts'): filename = file_info.get(ext) key = '%s_file' % ext[1:] file_info[key] = join(datadir, filename) if filename else None return file_info # First figure out if the data directory exists try: files = os.listdir(self._datadir) except OSError as err: if err.errno == errno.ENOTDIR: # If there's a file here instead of a directory, quarantine # it; something's gone wrong somewhere. raise self._quarantine( # hack: quarantine_renamer actually renames the directory # enclosing the filename you give it, but here we just # want this one file and not its parent. os.path.join(self._datadir, "made-up-filename"), "Expected directory, found file at %s" % self._datadir) elif err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise DiskFileError( "Error listing directory %s: %s" % (self._datadir, err)) # The data directory does not exist, so the object cannot exist. file_info = dict(data_file=None, meta_file=None, ts_file=None) else: # gather info about the valid files to us to open the DiskFile file_info = self._get_ondisk_file(files) data_file, meta_file, ts_file = \ itemgetter('data_file', 'meta_file', 'ts_file')(file_info) def _get_ondisk_file(self, files): Determine the on-disk files to use. :param files: a list of files in the object's dir :returns: dict of files to use having keys 'data_file', 'ts_file', 'meta_file' def _get_ondisk_file(self, files): return self.manager.get_ondisk_files(files, self._datadir) def _get_ondisk_file(self, files): return self.manager.get_ondisk_files( files, self._datadir, frag_index=self._frag_index) accepted_files.pop('.meta', None)
deleted_lines: :returns: a tuple of data, meta, and tombstone # maintain compatibility with 'legacy' get_ondisk_files return value accepted_files = self.gather_ondisk_files(files, verify=True, **kwargs) result = [(join(datadir, accepted_files.get(ext)) if accepted_files.get(ext) else None) for ext in ('.data', '.meta', '.ts')] return tuple(result) data_file, meta_file, ts_file = self._get_ondisk_file() def _get_ondisk_file(self): Do the work to figure out if the data directory exists, and if so, determine the on-disk files to use. :returns: a tuple of data, meta and ts (tombstone) files, in one of three states: * all three are None data directory does not exist, or there are no files in that directory * ts_file is not None, data_file is None, meta_file is None object is considered deleted * data_file is not None, ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata def _get_ondisk_file(self): """ Do the work to figure out if the data directory exists, and if so, determine the on-disk files to use. :returns: a tuple of data, meta and ts (tombstone) files, in one of three states: * all three are None data directory does not exist, or there are no files in that directory * ts_file is not None, data_file is None, meta_file is None object is considered deleted * data_file is not None, ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata """ try: files = os.listdir(self._datadir) except OSError as err: if err.errno == errno.ENOTDIR: # If there's a file here instead of a directory, quarantine # it; something's gone wrong somewhere. raise self._quarantine( # hack: quarantine_renamer actually renames the directory # enclosing the filename you give it, but here we just # want this one file and not its parent. os.path.join(self._datadir, "made-up-filename"), "Expected directory, found file at %s" % self._datadir) elif err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise DiskFileError( "Error listing directory %s: %s" % (self._datadir, err)) # The data directory does not exist, so the object cannot exist. fileset = (None, None, None) else: fileset = self.manager.get_ondisk_files(files, self._datadir) return fileset def _get_ondisk_file(self): try: files = os.listdir(self._datadir) except OSError as err: if err.errno == errno.ENOTDIR: # If there's a file here instead of a directory, quarantine # it; something's gone wrong somewhere. raise self._quarantine( # hack: quarantine_renamer actually renames the directory # enclosing the filename you give it, but here we just # want this one file and not its parent. os.path.join(self._datadir, "made-up-filename"), "Expected directory, found file at %s" % self._datadir) elif err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise DiskFileError( "Error listing directory %s: %s" % (self._datadir, err)) # The data directory does not exist, so the object cannot exist. fileset = (None, None, None) else: fileset = self.manager.get_ondisk_files( files, self._datadir, frag_index=self._frag_index) return fileset accepted_files['.meta'] = None

Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-07-08 00:28:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/350c1de84b3a5962495e261ea57ed7a4f4f202b4', 'message': "WIP Generic image cache.

Note: Still needs a bunch of tests, but is otherwise mostly of working.

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images. If enabled, and the
cinder internal tenant is configured, it will create a minimal sized
clone of a volume the first time it is downloaded from glance. A new db
table image_volume_cache tracks these volumes, which are owned by the
Cinder internal tenant. The original will then be extended to full size.
Any subsequent requests to create a volume from an image will be able
to do a volume clone from the image-volume cache entry instead of
downloading the image data from glance again.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if size is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes do not
take any quota from *any* user. They are only limited by the cache size
configuration options.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.


DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it.

Implements: image-volume-cache

Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2015-07-21 02:42:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e46118de8478ad993fc7d0a5c8c17692844d2990', 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

It will also create an entry upon creating an image from a volume right
before uploading the volume to glance.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Implements: image-volume-cache

create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

It will also create an entry upon creating an image from a volume right
before uploading the volume to glance.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Implements: image-volume-cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

This functionality requires an image to have its virtual_size set in
its Glance metadata. With the v2 glance API certain workflows to create
images will automatically set this, but for others it will require a
manual step to set the virtual_size property on the image.

Future changes to Glance and Cinder can make this more automated to
set the virtual size any chance we can. For example when creating a
volume from image though the default driver implementation in Cinder
we actually get the virtual size from a qemu-img command. We could
potentially set it on the image automatically for a user. This is
however something to be done on top of the initial cache functionality
and would be added later on in another change.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Implements: image-volume-cache

images will automatically set this, but for others it will require a
manual step to set the virtual_size property on the image.

Future changes to Glance and Cinder can make this more automated to
set the virtual size any chance we can. For example when creating a
volume from image though the default driver implementation in Cinder
we actually get the virtual size from a qemu-img command. We could
potentially set it on the image automatically for a user. This is
however something to be done on top of the initial cache functionality
and would be added later on in another change.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Implements: image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f

downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Co-Authored-By: Tomoki Sekiyama <tomoki.sekiyama@hds.com>

Implements: image-volume-cache

"}, {'number': 52, 'created': '2015-08-31 03:02:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/32bfb5868a1ff8ab1f8b773ac9ab75656a86615a', 'message': "Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

commit_message:
Generic image-volume cache

This introduces a new feature for backends to be able to use cached
glance images when creating volumes from images.

If enabled, and the cinder internal tenant is configured, it will
create a minimal sized clone of a volume the first time it is
downloaded from glance. A new db table image_volume_cache tracks
these volumes, which are owned by the Cinder internal tenant. The
original will then be extended to full size. Any subsequent requests to
create a volume from an image will be able to do a volume clone from
the image-volume cache entry instead of downloading the image data from
glance again.

In the future we could create an entry upon creating an image from a
volume right before uploading the volume to glance. This version
however does not aim to do more than add the initial framework and
help with subsequent image downloads. There are certainly more
improvements that can be done over time on top of this.

These image-volumes are host specific, so each backend may end up with
its very own image-volume to do clones from.

The cache is limited in size by number of entries allowed and size in
gb. When creating a new entry if space is needed the last used entries
will be evicted to make room.

In the current implementation the image-volumes will be viewable by a
cloud admin in the volume list, and show up as owned by the Cinder
internal tenant. They can safely be deleted manually by an admin, this
will cause the entry to be removed from the cache. These volumes will
use quota for the internal tenant.

Cache actions will post notifications to Ceilometer. There are
notifications like image_volume_cache.miss, image_volume_cache.hit,
and image_volume_cache.evict. A change will be required to the
event_definitions.yaml to see them nicely. Until then you only need to
add a new event type 'image_volume_cache.*' and look for the image_id
and host fields.

DocImpact: We probably want some instructions on restrictions of the
cache and how to use it. The three new config options should also be
documented somewhere: image_volume_cache_enabled,
image_volume_cache_max_size_gb, image_volume_cache_max_size_count

Co-Authored-By: Tomoki Sekiyama <tomoki.sekiyama@hds.com>

Implements: blueprint image-volume-cache
Change-Id: If22bbaff89251e4e82a715170a48b4040f95c09f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/195795/42 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ImageVolumeCacheEntry(BASE, models.ModelBase): """Represents an image volume cache entry""" __tablename__ = 'image_volume_cache' id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False) host_id = Column(String(255), index=True, nullable=False) image_id = Column(String(36), index=True, nullable=False) image_updated_at = Column(DateTime, nullable=False) volume_id = Column(String(36), nullable=False)

Let's use it properly.

commit_message:
Add spec for major update of haproxy role

Implements: blueprint role-haproxy-v2
Change-Id: I3d916ae0f136a440dd940b26277c04b7b3dbbb5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs refs/changes/89/214089/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Rewriting HA Proxy for new features ################################# :date: 2015-08-18 11:00 :tags: haproxy HA Proxy currently suffers from a lack of HA/scaling features: * It tries to restart even if he doesn't hold the IP * It tries (by default) to check backends for services that aren't deployed yet We could then add the keepalived feature to have a VIP and start/stop haproxy https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+spec/haproxy-rewrite Problem description =================== A detailed description of the problem: * HA Proxy doesn't know if it runs on a VIP or not * For the deployer, HA Proxy playbook fails run when deployed on multiple nodes if a VIP is used and one of the nodes can't bind on this VIP. * HA Proxy is deployed with all the backends, whether or not the service is deployed. Proposed change =============== * Rewrite the haproxy playbook to avoid the unnecessary pre_ and post_ tasks. * Call whenever possible the existing work (haproxy_server role and tasks) * Change handlers for the service restart * Change the tasks in order to make them conditional Alternatives ------------ Wait for ansible2 in order to have a better rewrite of this: * New ansible2 features will bring shorter * Variable definition and overwriting will be easier Playbook/Role impact -------------------- The playbook haproxy-install.yml should be replaced by this one. Upgrade impact -------------- The "legacy" part of the haproxy-install.yml playbook will be brought in a new playbook that should be runned to cleanup old haproxy configuration. Security impact --------------- No change Performance impact ------------------ Less unnecessary checks to unavailable backends End user impact --------------- No change Deployer impact --------------- * No change in default configuration * Changes to the default configuration won't happen unless mentionned in each service variable file * If you use different configuration for your HA proxy, changes will have to be done in your user variables to overwrite the default configuration Developer impact ---------------- No impact at first sight. Dependencies ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None Work items ---------- * HA Proxy rewrite without the possibility of overwriting the variables * Adding the feature for overwriting default variables Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. You should be able to answer the following questions: * Does this change impact how gating is done? There will be a change to haproxy-install playbook if merged. * Can this change be tested on a **per-commit** basis? Yes * Given the instance size restrictions, as found in OpenStack Infra (8GB Ram, vCPUs <= 8), can the test be run in a resource constrained environment? Yes * Is this untestable given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans for this change to be tested within 3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc...? No * If the service is not OpenStack specific how can we test the change? Running the new playbooks Documentation impact ==================== For those who change the default configuration of haproxy (currently not documented), this change would modify their current configuration, so it needs to be documented. References ========== None

commit_message:
Add spec for Independent Role Repositories

Implements: blueprint independent-role-repositories

Change-Id: I2cd110009c8518ec209674a2e5941a4ff6b810be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs refs/changes/79/213779/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Independent Role Repositories ############################# :date: 2015-08-17 14:00 :tags: roles In order to improve the ability to independently consume the roles produced by openstack-ansible in different reference use-case deployments and allow independent development of each role by different projects, this specification proposes that each role be broken out of the current monolithic repository into seperate repositories named ``openstack/openstack-ansible-<role>``. * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+spec/independent-role-repositories This provides the following benefits: * Other projects (eg: Kolla, Compass, RPC, etc) will be able to consume the roles using their own playbooks. This increases the opportunity for other projects to collaborate with openstack-ansible. * The roles will be more easily consumed in different reference architectures. Currently the playbooks and roles are specifically geared for deployment in LXC containers. Making the roles independant entities will allow them to be consumed for completely different architectures. eg: a deployment without containers, a deployment with VM's instead of containers, a deployment with a different container technology * Each role can have its own independant core teams, providing the opportunity for subject matter experts (SME's) to safeguard the core functionality provided by the role from an educated standpoint. * Each role can be developed at its own pace and versioned independently. This will make openstack-ansible more like the OpenStack "Big Tent". * Each role can be independently gate checked with checks that are specific and relevant to the role. This will provide quicker developer feedback and allow a quicker turnaround for development. * The roles can be registered in Ansible Galaxy. This will provide greater awareness of the roles and may attract more contributors. This is especially useful for the infrastructure roles. (eg: haproxy, MariaDB, etc) * Role seperation will improve code discipline. For the role to be usable as an independent unit without knowledge of the playbooks consuming it we will be forced to ensure that any variables we consume in the role are defined and used properly. * Role seperation will simplify the mission of openstack-ansible's playbooks and scripts to be for the purpose of providing examples of how to consume the roles and to implement gate testing for integrated deployment verification of the use-cases that matter to the community. This prevents the situation where the playbooks have to cater for every possible combination use-case that may be thrown at them. Problem description =================== A detailed description of the problem: * Currently the openstack-ansible roles are tightly coupled with the playbooks that consume them. While the roles can technically be consumed using different playbooks, this is not immediately obvious to downstream consumers. * When consumers to try to consume the roles with different playbooks for a different architecture, they are forced to implement many workarounds for the tight coupling that we have. Even when it is possible to do, it is hard for a deployer to see how to do it due to the deluge of variables that need to be set and code that needs to be read. * There has been some interest in creating roles for other services (eg: rally, congress, etc). Implementing the strategy of a repo per role allows these fledgling roles to get into the open and get collaborated on far more quickly. Once they're at the point where they're ready to be integrated into an integrated use-case with integration gate tests, then they can tag a version and implement the openstack-ansible playbooks and scripts to test the appropriate use-case. * The infrastructure roles implemented as part of the project are not getting much attention as they are more like a second-class citizen within the role structure. This results in the configurations deployed often not lining up to best-practises. * Any small changes to roles require the execution of a full integration gate test which is slow and prone to error. It is difficult to isolate the error in the current monolithic stack. Proposed change =============== The following process should be followed: #. For each role targeted for breaking out, a seperate blueprint must be registered and a spec provided for the high level changes that would be required in the current os-ansible-deployment playbooks and roles to accommodate this change. #. Once the spec is approved, the review to register the new repository should be registered upstream. #. Once the new repository has been created, extract the role from the master branch with its history and push it into the new repository. #. Implement a submodule in the os-ansible-deployment repository in place of the removed role. This is to simplify the transition while the work is done to implement the changes in the new role and the os-ansible-deployment playbooks/scripts. Fix the submodule to the starting SHA so that other work can continue while changes are implemented in the role repository. #. Once gate independent gate checks on the role repository confirm that it is in working order and the work is done to prepare the role for usage in the integrated use-cases, tag the initial version of the role and implement the os-ansible-deployment playbook, script and submodule SHA changes to consume the new role. #. Finally, switch from using the submodule to using ansible-galaxy to import the role. Once this is verified to be working successfully, remove the submodule. Alternatives ------------ Leave everything as it is. Playbook/Role impact -------------------- The impact to playbooks should be fairly incremental, but will need to be determined on a role by role basis. This must be described in the spec on a per role basis. Each role will have to: * carry any modules/filters that it consumes that are not available in the upstream ansible repositories. * operate without the dynamic inventory. Upgrade impact -------------- As this will be done in master, the upgrade impact will have to be determined and resolved in a specific spec which will probably have to be prepared later in the cycle. Security impact --------------- n/a Performance impact ------------------ n/a End user impact --------------- End users will not know of any differences. Deployer impact --------------- The structure and placement of roles on the deployment host will be different. The changes will need to be documented for support purposes. However, the configuration and execution of the existing playbooks for downstream consumers should be targeted to be exactly the same to minimise disruption. Any role-specific impacts will need to be defined on a per-role basis. Developer impact ---------------- The biggest negative developer impact will be the difficulty working between the two different structures - master being split, with liberty and kilo being consolidated. It may be worth considering ways to make them all work the same way once the conversions are done for master. The positive impact has been outlined in the introduction. Dependencies ------------ This should only be implemented after liberty has been released. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: https://launchpad.net/~jesse-pretorius ``odyssey4me`` https://launchpad.net/~kevin-carter ``cloudnull`` Other contributors: TBD Work items ---------- See proposed change section. Testing ======= The testing impact will need to be described on a per-role basis. As a standard, the following tests are expected to be implemented as a standard for each role: * bashate tests for all shell scripts * pep8 tests for all python files * ansible syntax checks for all ansible task files * ansible-lint tests for all ansible task files * functional tests for the service Integration tests are expected to be implemented in the os-ansible-deployment repository and executed whenever the role versions are incremented. Documentation impact ==================== While the placement of the role files on the deployment host will be different, the configuration and execution of the deployment should remain the same, resulting in minimal documentation impact. References ========== n/a

commit_message:
Add unit tests for signature_utils class

This patch adds unit tests for the signature_utils class,
which adds image signing functionality to Glance.

Depends-On: I0b0592a3526a4e4f5b39ae6ce8b4dedd0ccc31d9
Change-Id: I1180501ff63e5148fd9e29bc4b9922fd485b6ab7
Implements: blueprint image-signing-and-verification-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/26/214726/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) The Johns Hopkins University/Applied Physics Laboratory # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import base64 from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import padding from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import rsa from glance.common import exception from glance.common import signature_utils from glance.tests import utils as test_utils import mock TEST_PRIVATE_KEY = rsa.generate_private_key(public_exponent=3, key_size=1024, backend=default_backend()) class FakeKeyManager(object): def __init__(self): self.certs = {'invalid_format_cert': FakeCertificate('A' * 256, 'B' * 256, 'BLAH'), 'valid_format_cert': FakeCertificate('A' * 256, 'B' * 256, 'X.509')} def get(self, context, certificate_uuid): cert = self.certs.get(certificate_uuid) if cert == None: raise Exception("No matching certificate found.") return cert class FakeCertificate(object): def __init__(self, data, pub_key, cert_format): self.data = data self.pub_key = pub_key self.cert_format = cert_format def public_key(self): return self.pub_key def get_format(self): return self.cert_format def get_encoded(self): return self.data class TestSignatureUtils(test_utils.BaseTestCase): """Test methods of signature_utils""" def test_should_verify_signature(self): image_props = {'certificate_uuid': 'CERT_UUID', 'signature_hash_method': 'HASH_METHOD', 'signature': 'SIGNATURE', 'signature_format': 'SIG_FORMAT'} self.assertTrue(signature_utils.should_verify_signature(image_props)) def test_should_verify_signature_fail(self): bad_image_properties = [{'certificate_uuid': 'CERT_UUID', 'signature_hash_method': 'HASH_METHOD', 'signature': 'SIGNATURE'}, {'certificate_uuid': 'CERT_UUID', 'signature_hash_method': 'HASH_METHOD', 'signature_format': 'SIG_FORMAT'}, {'certificate_uuid': 'CERT_UUID', 'signature': 'SIGNATURE', 'signature_format': 'SIG_FORMAT'}, {'signature_hash_method': 'HASH_METHOD', 'signature': 'SIGNATURE', 'signature_format': 'SIG_FORMAT'}] for bad_props in bad_image_properties: result = signature_utils.should_verify_signature(bad_props) self.assertFalse(result) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_public_key') def test_verify_signature_PSS(self, mock_get_pub_key): checksum_hash = '224626ae19824466f2a7f39ab7b80f7f' mock_get_pub_key.return_value = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() for hash_name, hash_alg in signature_utils.HASH_METHODS.iteritems(): signer = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.signer( padding.PSS( mgf=padding.MGF1(hash_alg), salt_length=padding.PSS.MAX_LENGTH ), hash_alg ) signer.update(checksum_hash) signature = base64.b64encode(signer.finalize()) image_props = {'certificate_uuid': 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0693', 'signature_hash_method': hash_name, 'signature_format': 'RSA-PSS', 'mask_gen_algorithm': 'MGF1', 'signature': signature} self.assertTrue(signature_utils.verify_signature(None, checksum_hash, image_props)) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_public_key') def test_verify_signature_bad_signature(self, mock_get_pub_key): checksum_hash = '224626ae19824466f2a7f39ab7b80f7f' mock_get_pub_key.return_value = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() image_properties = {'certificate_uuid': 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0693', 'signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', 'signature_format': 'RSA-PSS', 'mask_gen_algorithm': 'MGF1', 'signature': 'BLAH'} self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.verify_signature, None, checksum_hash, image_properties) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.should_verify_signature') def test_verify_signature_invalid_image_props(self, mock_should): mock_should.return_value = False self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.verify_signature, None, None, None) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_public_key') def test_verify_signature_bad_sig_format(self, mock_get_pub_key): checksum_hash = '224626ae19824466f2a7f39ab7b80f7f' mock_get_pub_key.return_value = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() image_properties = {'certificate_uuid': 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0693', 'signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', 'signature_format': 'BLAH', 'mask_gen_algorithm': 'MGF1', 'signature': 'BLAH'} self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.verify_signature, None, checksum_hash, image_properties) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_public_key') def test_verify_signature_RSA_no_mask_gen(self, mock_get_pub_key): checksum_hash = '224626ae19824466f2a7f39ab7b80f7f' mock_get_pub_key.return_value = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() image_properties = {'certificate_uuid': 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0693', 'signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', 'signature_format': 'RSA-PSS', 'signature': 'BLAH'} self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.verify_signature, None, checksum_hash, image_properties) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_public_key') def test_verify_signature_RSA_bad_mask_gen(self, mock_get_pub_key): checksum_hash = '224626ae19824466f2a7f39ab7b80f7f' mock_get_pub_key.return_value = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() image_properties = {'certificate_uuid': 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0693', 'signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', 'signature_format': 'RSA-PSS', 'mask_gen_algorithm': 'BLAH', 'signature': 'BLAH'} self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.verify_signature, None, checksum_hash, image_properties) def test_get_signature(self): signature = 'A' * 256 data = base64.b64encode(signature) self.assertEqual(signature, signature_utils.get_signature(data)) def test_get_hash_method(self): hash_dict = signature_utils.HASH_METHODS for hash_name in hash_dict.keys(): hash_class = signature_utils.get_hash_method(hash_name).__class__ self.assertIsInstance(hash_dict[hash_name], hash_class) def test_get_hash_method_fail(self): self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.get_hash_method, 'SHA-2') def test_get_signature_format(self): for sig_format in signature_utils.SIGNATURE_FORMATS: self.assertEqual(sig_format, signature_utils.get_signature_format(sig_format)) def test_get_signature_format_fail(self): self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.get_signature_format, 'RSB-PSS') @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_certificate') def test_get_public_key(self, mock_get_certificate): RSA_public_key = TEST_PRIVATE_KEY.public_key() mock_get_certificate.return_value = FakeCertificate('A' * 256, RSA_public_key, 'X.509') result_pub_key = signature_utils.get_public_key(None, None, 'RSA-PSS') self.assertEqual(RSA_public_key, result_pub_key) @mock.patch('glance.common.signature_utils.get_certificate') def test_get_public_key_invalid_key(self, mock_get_certificate): bad_public_key = 'A' * 256 mock_get_certificate.return_value = FakeCertificate('A' * 256, bad_public_key, 'X.509') self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.get_public_key, context=None, certificate_uuid=None, signature_format='RSA-PSS') @mock.patch('cryptography.x509.load_pem_x509_certificate') @mock.patch('castellan.key_manager.API', return_value=FakeKeyManager()) def test_get_certificate(self, mock_key_manager_API, mock_load_cert): cert_uuid = 'valid_format_cert' expected_cert_data = 'EXPECTED_VALUE' mock_load_cert.return_value = expected_cert_data self.assertEqual(expected_cert_data, signature_utils.get_certificate(None, cert_uuid)) @mock.patch('castellan.key_manager.API', return_value=FakeKeyManager()) def test_get_certificate_key_manager_fail(self, mock_key_manager_API): bad_cert_uuid = 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0695' self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.get_certificate, context=None, certificate_uuid=bad_cert_uuid) @mock.patch('castellan.key_manager.API', return_value=FakeKeyManager()) def test_get_certificate_invalid_format(self, mock_API): cert_uuid = 'fea14bc2-d75f-4ba5-bccc-b5c924ad0694' self.assertRaises(exception.SignatureVerificationError, signature_utils.get_certificate, context=None, certificate_uuid=cert_uuid)

commit_message:
live-migration: Logs exception if operation failed

Live-migration can fail silently, without proper logging, making it
hard to determine the cause of the failure.

Closes-Bug: #1489874

Change-Id: Ib70dafd6fe2658ae9a1a43d177f4ed2c99a10c04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/22/217822/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except Exception as ex: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error("Exception encountered: %s", ex)

subject: Use admin context in octavia driver, improve logs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-21 03:46:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/62ab384a2e2aebabecb5a8ea3b025980e52dc4a4', 'message': 'Use admin context in octavia driver, improve logs

When polling for the status of a load balancer in octavia, the context created
by the plugin was being used.  Since the polling takes place in a thread, that
context can have some unexpected behavior.  It is better to create an admin
context in the thread because it definitely exists in that thread.

Also improve debug logging in the octavia driver and the successful and failed
completion helper methods in the mixins.

Change-Id: I6f64c95d89876c9d1d19076a4fe7e3006a0df5e0
Closes-Bug: #1497823

commit_message:
Use admin context in octavia driver, improve logs

When polling for the status of a load balancer in octavia, the context created
by the plugin was being used.  Since the polling takes place in a thread, that
context can have some unexpected behavior.  It is better to create an admin
context in the thread because it definitely exists in that thread.

Also improve debug logging in the octavia driver and the successful and failed
completion helper methods in the mixins.

Change-Id: I6f64c95d89876c9d1d19076a4fe7e3006a0df5e0
Closes-Bug: #1497823

deleted_lines: def thread_op(manager, context, entity, delete=False): args=(args[0], args[1], args[2]), LOG.debug("r = %s", r)

commit_message:
Relax newly imposed sql driver restriction for domain config

The first implementation of the domain config API introduced a
new restriction in terms of which identity drivers could be SQL
backend (to avoid potential multi-process race conditions). This
restriction specified that only the default domain could be SQL
backend.

This patch resolves these issues and hence ensures the restrictions
in terms of SQL identity drivers are the same as the original config
file based approach (i.e. only one driver can be SQL backend, but
it can be for any given domain).

Although this patch changes the V8 driver interface, this is for
the domain_config backend which is still marked as experimental.

Closes-Bug: #1450344
Change-Id: Id1b4415cb5f263dc7afd9e25bd0da2b667f1c90a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/76/191976/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ConfigMutex(sql.ModelBase, sql.ModelDictMixin): __tablename__ = 'config_mutex' mutex = sql.Column(sql.String(64), primary_key=True) domain_id = sql.Column(sql.String(64), nullable=False) SQL_MUTEX = 'SQL' # SQL Mutex methods def _create_sql_mutex(self, session, domain_id): ref = ConfigMutex(mutex=SQL_MUTEX, domain_id=domain_id) session.add(ref) def obtain_sql_mutex(self, domain_id): try: with sql.transaction() as session: self._create_sql_mutex(session, domain_id) return True except sql.DBDuplicateEntry: # OK, so someone already has the mutex, before we give up we # should check that it isn't our own domain. try: with sql.transaction() as session: ref = session.query(ConfigMutex).get(SQL_MUTEX) domain_with_mutex = ref.domain_id except sql.NotFound: # Just maybe another process deleted it, so try and grab it try: with sql.transaction() as session: self._create_sql_mutex(session, domain_id) domain_with_mutex = domain_id except sql.DBDuplicateEntry: return False return domain_with_mutex == domain_id def read_sql_mutex(self): with sql.transaction() as session: ref = session.query(ConfigMutex).get(SQL_MUTEX) if not ref: raise exception.NotFound return ref.domain_id def free_sql_mutex(self, domain_id): with sql.transaction() as session: ref = session.query(ConfigMutex).get(SQL_MUTEX) if ref: session.delete(ref)

commit_message:
Clean up CIMC driver docs and comments

Based on comments on the original commit, this patch fixes a few minor
issues that were picked up.

commit_message:
Add Cisco IMC PXE Driver

Current drivers only allow for control of UCS servers via either IPMI or
UCSM, the Cisco UCS C-Series operating in standalone mode can also be
controlled via CIMC using its http/s XML API. This provides finer
control over the server than IPMI can, and doesn't require the extra
infrastructure that UCSM needs.

Change-Id: Ibd39040e3d7e82a87960d33150750433beb2453b
Implements: blueprint cisco-imc-pxe-driver

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-19 07:37:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0dfca15c768249eac2d7b83298a1b07ca843325d', 'message': 'Hyper-V: Implements detach_interface method

Neutron events have been added to nova. If the event
"network-vif-unplugged" is received, the nova compute manager
will proceed to call the compute driver's detach_interface method.
The mentioned method is not implemented in the HyperVDriver,
causing errors.

On Windows Hyper-V / Server 2012 R2 (kernel version 6.4), vNICs
can be attached / detached while the VM are running, if the VM
is generation 2.

Adds detach_interface method implementation.

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Implements attach_interface and detach_interface method

Neutron events have been added to nova. If the event
"network-vif-unplugged" is received, the nova compute manager
will proceed to call the compute driver's detach_interface method.
The mentioned method is not implemented in the HyperVDriver,
causing errors.

On Windows Hyper-V / Server Threshold (kernel version 10.0), vNICs
can be attached / detached while the VM are running, if the VM
is generation 2.

Adds attach_interface and detach_interface method implementations.

Co-Authored-By: Adelina Tuvenie <atuvenie@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Closes-Bug: #1486410
Change-Id: I6e0f6a8373810560ae2fadc99b7dd57c06391c96

commit_message:
Remove "shelved_image_id" key from instance system metadata

In the unit test case "test_unshelve_instance_schedule_and_rebuild_volume_backed
", set the "shelved_image_id" to the instance system metadata,
it tests the instance boot from image, not boot from volume.
So it needs to remove "shelved_image_id" from the  metadata,
and remove "image_api.get" mock method.

Change-Id: Ie501acaaa1c961a4b6f1f4ea9726a5b11b0de709
Closes-Bug: #1485429
Signed-off-by: Xiaowei Qian <qianxw.fnst@cn.fujitsu.com>

revisions:

The libvirt inspector may can't inspect data from libvirt on some occasions after
libvirtd is restarted, though we have reconnecting logic. When this occurs, it will
raise libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR instead of libvirt.VIR_ERR_SYSTEM_ERROR in
reconnecting logic. This results compute agent no longer reconnects to libvirt, and
fails to inspect data any more. This patch is just updated to deal with INTERNAL_ERROR.

Change-Id: Ifbd754cb050ec7e364d17fea3b32191da1e22ef5
Closes-bug: #1498013
"}]
commit_message:
Fix reconnecting to libvirt

The libvirt inspector may can't inspect data from libvirt on some occasions after
libvirtd is restarted, though we have reconnecting logic. When this occurs, it will
raise libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR instead of libvirt.VIR_ERR_SYSTEM_ERROR in
reconnecting logic. This results compute agent no longer reconnects to libvirt, and
fails to inspect data any more. This patch is just updated to deal with INTERNAL_ERROR.

Change-Id: Ifbd754cb050ec7e364d17fea3b32191da1e22ef5
Closes-bug: #1498013

commit_message:
Removing "skip" decorators for some OpenStack actions tests

Bug #1422725 has been fixed and now there is no need to skip
test_heat_actions and test_neutron_actions tests. This patch
removes "skip" decorators for these tests.

Depends-on: I745b9fd7fa2a36bbe97e17e3441f9cda4b8ea33f

subject: Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-21 18:45:21.000000000', 'files': ['rpc_deployment/roles/swift_object/templates/object-server.conf.j2', 'rpc_deployment/roles/swift_account/templates/account-server.conf.j2', 'rpc_deployment/inventory/group_vars/swift_all.yml', 'rpc_deployment/roles/swift_container/templates/container-server.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/8a4bf7f5bfc272a1ffd9c7960dd9064e74328386', 'message': "Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock

The Swift configuration item [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path is set to
'/var/lock/swift' by openstack-ansible in the appropriate configuration
files. The playbooks also create the directory if it does not exist. If
the host is rebooted the directory '/var/lock/swift' is missing and must
be recreated.

/var/lock (/run/lock) is a tmpfs and so the directory /var/lock/swift
will not persist between reboots.

Swift attempts to create a directory in the directory specified by
recon_lock_path however it does not recursively create any missing
parent directories.

This commit changes the value of [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path to that
set by Swift, '/var/lock'. This allows it to create the directory
'/var/lock/swift-recon-object-cron'. The creation of '/var/lock/swift'
is also removed from the playbooks.

Change-Id: I714367b02c7cf961e9e0bdee4e41f9e4e105b088
Closes-bug: #1496117
(cherry picked from commit 176107aa3026ce03a09bd9a62e7a100e58d2cccc)
"}]
commit_message:
Change recon_lock_path to /var/lock

The Swift configuration item [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path is set to
'/var/lock/swift' by openstack-ansible in the appropriate configuration
files. The playbooks also create the directory if it does not exist. If
the host is rebooted the directory '/var/lock/swift' is missing and must
be recreated.

/var/lock (/run/lock) is a tmpfs and so the directory /var/lock/swift
will not persist between reboots.

Swift attempts to create a directory in the directory specified by
recon_lock_path however it does not recursively create any missing
parent directories.

This commit changes the value of [filter:recon]/recon_lock_path to that
set by Swift, '/var/lock'. This allows it to create the directory
'/var/lock/swift-recon-object-cron'. The creation of '/var/lock/swift'
is also removed from the playbooks.

Conflicts:
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/tasks/swift_pre_install.yml
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/account-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/container-server.conf.j2
  playbooks/roles/os_swift/templates/object-server.conf.j2

Change-Id: I714367b02c7cf961e9e0bdee4e41f9e4e105b088
Closes-bug: #1496117
(cherry picked from commit 176107aa3026ce03a09bd9a62e7a100e58d2cccc)

commit_message:
devref: Add bug handling description to developer reference

The bug handling in nova is described over a few wiki pages. It also
missed some information a new developer would need to understand the
process. An adoption and review of the process with the core reviewers
and the bug-supervisors is hard to do.

This patch set adds a page to the developer reference and should be
the "single source of truth" one needs to read to be able to
participate in the bug handling process of nova.

Partially Implements: blueprint devref-refresh-liberty

Change-Id: I4c306e4201fecc17aee2714e3075b5d1d291a322
Depends-On: Ia699fd1965b475f2633ecfc555bc766eb5aa3404

commit_message:
Adding Intel f10k DKMS kernel module on bootstrap for CentOS

Change-Id: I0360af880c4d66f0d07513f293098ce538db70e7
Closes-bug: #1484077
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/13/215913/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fm10k-dkms \

subject: Volume status management during migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-28 07:52:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/800516effa67866de6ca5916e8f313733d83b121', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration fails.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeds.

The volume status should be set to 'migrating' during migration and
goes back to its original status after migration.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration fails.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeds.

The volume status should be set to 'maintenance' during migration and
goes back to its original status after migration, if the admin issues
the migrate command with the flag --force.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode.

"}, {'number': 29, 'created': '2015-07-10 04:34:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e3e03b6871c267f3147faf4af23b7ad16c063e88', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the --force flag is used, the volume status should be set to
'maintenance' during migration and goes back to its original status
after migration. Otherwise, if the --force flag is not used or set
to True, the volume status will remain the same as its original
status.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be terminated if other requests
are issued, e.g. attach.

DocImpact
APIImpact The --force flag has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partially-implements-blueprint: migration-improvement

"}, {'number': 33, 'created': '2015-07-13 07:38:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/4bd86e47331c43f0170743daf999560612c4ef5e', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the --force flag is used, the volume status should be set to
'maintenance' during migration and goes back to its original status
after migration. Otherwise, if the --force flag is not used or set
to True, the volume status will remain the same as its original
status.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be terminated if other requests
are issued, e.g. attach.

DocImpact
APIImpact The --force flag has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partially-implements-blueprint: migration-improvement

"}, {'number': 48, 'created': '2015-07-24 00:18:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/5fd65381cb5a79c41b2c68228d61d076d3cd5eae', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the key 'force' flag is set to True from the request, the volume
status should be set to 'maintenance' during migration and goes
back to its original status after migration. Otherwise, if the
key 'force' is set to False, the volume status will remain the
same as its original status.

All the actions, including attach, detach, etc, are not allowed
when the volume is in 'maintenance' mode. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be interrupted if other requests
are issued, e.g. attach. For the termination of migration, another
patch will target to resolve it.

DocImpact
APIImpact The key 'force' has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partial-implements: blueprint migration-improvement
Depends-On: I915c279b526e7268d68ab18ce01200ae22deabdd

"}, {'number': 51, 'created': '2015-07-29 07:25:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e385e4653b73069ad42e67c6265544b560f0ebd0', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the key 'force' is set to True from the request, the volume
status should be set to 'maintenance' during migration and goes
back to its original status after migration. Otherwise, if the
key 'force' is set to False, the volume status will remain the
same as its original status.

From the REST's perspetives, all the create, update and delete
actions are not allowed if the volume is in 'maintenance', because
it means the volume out of service. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be interrupted if other requests are
issued, e.g. attach. For the termination of migration, another
patch will target to resolve it.

DocImpact
APIImpact The key 'force' has been added into the API, telling the
volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partial-implements: blueprint migration-improvement

"}, {'number': 53, 'created': '2015-07-30 06:59:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/340365c9a6d92113b16a89ea33f0e96f469e554f', 'message': "Volume status management during migration

The initial migration_status is None, meaning no migration has been
done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

If the key 'lock_volume' is set to True from the request, the volume
status should be set to 'maintenance' during migration and goes
back to its original status after migration. Otherwise, if the
key 'force' is set to False, the volume status will remain the
same as its original status.

From the REST's perspetives, all the create, update and delete
actions are not allowed if the volume is in 'maintenance', because
it means the volume out of service. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be interrupted if other requests are
issued, e.g. attach. For the termination of migration, another
patch will target to resolve it.

DocImpact
APIImpact The key 'lock_volume' has been added into the API,
telling the volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partial-implements: blueprint migration-improvement

actions are not allowed if the volume is in 'maintenance', because
it means the volume out of service. If it is not in maintenance
mode, the migration can be interrupted if other requests are
issued, e.g. attach. For the termination of migration, another
patch will target to resolve it.

DocImpact
APIImpact The key 'lock_volume' has been added into the API,
telling the volume to change the status to 'maintenance' or not.

Change-Id: Ia86421f2d6fce61dcfeb073f8e7b9c9dde517373
Partial-implements: blueprint migration-improvement

done. Migration_status 'error' means the previous migration failed.
Migration_status 'success' means the previous migration succeeded.

back to its original status after migration. Otherwise, if the
key 'lock_volume' is set to False, the volume status will remain the
same as its original status.

actions are not allowed if the volume is in 'maintenance', because

mode, the migration can be interrupted if other requests are
issued, e.g. attach. For the termination of migration, another
patch will target to resolve it.
